column2: What is your email address? - Email
column3: Thinking about the occasion when you flew anywhere as part of a group that booked tickets together, please tell us when this occasion happened. If you are unsure, please give your best estimate.  - Occasion
column4: Including yourself, how many, if any, of each of the following types of people were in the group that you booked for? - People booked for - Adult(s) aged 17 years or older
column5: Including yourself, how many, if any, of each of the following types of people were in the group that you booked for? - People booked for - Children aged 13 to 16 years old
column6: Including yourself, how many, if any, of each of the following types of people were in the group that you booked for? - People booked for - Children aged 2 to 12 years old
column7: Including yourself, how many, if any, of each of the following types of people were in the group that you booked for? - People booked for - Infant(s) aged 2 or under
column8:
For the following question, by “disability, health or medical condition”, we mean physical conditions affecting movement, balance, vision or hearing, or non-physical disabilities or health conditions (e.g. affecting thinking, remembering, learning, communications, mental health or social relationships). It could also include a temporary condition that could be impacted by air travel such as pregnancy or injury. 

Did yourself or anyone else in the group booking have a disability, health or medical condition that would have an impact on travelling? - Disability, health or medical conditions
column9: Which one, if any, of the following airlines was your flight with? If your answer doesn’t appear in the list, pleas type it in the “other” box - Airline
column10: Which one, if any, of the following airlines was your flight with? If your answer doesn’t appear in the list, pleas type it in the “other” box - Other
column11: Which one of the following BEST describes why you didn’t sit together? - Seating
column12: If you paid extra to guarantee sitting together, approximately how much money did you pay, per seat, to sit together? If you are unsure please give your best estimate. - Cost
column13:
Tell us about your experience of seating arrangements. If there are any relevant details about your group booking that are not covered by the questions above, please explain them here. Please tell us whether you reported any concerns to the airline and if so, how these were handled.
(500 words max.) - Your experience
column20: Browser Identification

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13: Situation was not taken up with airline. Having booked via Broadway Travel and we didn't take priority boarding, so were told to check in 4 days before both out and return flights, which were 3 days apart. On checking for the first flight, the system asked if we wanted to book seats or take random allocated seating. Having flown Easyjet many times we have not booked sets but have always been allocated seats together, so expected similar with Ryanair.  When the boarding passes came through I was in row 15 and my wife in 10 which made us quite upset as my wife is a nervous passenger, so when booking the return flight we paid extra to sit together.  When doing this a highlighted pop up statement said "we note you are sitting apart on the outgoing flight" this offered us the option to change seats " Cost From £2" I was amazed to find that the seat next to me was available but at £8, which we took. It is very clear that Ryanair's system deliberately seated us apart even though 3 days later the seat next to me was not taken. This is a system is obviously designed to make us pay more otherwise my wife would have been sat next to me in the first instance.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.119 Safari/537.36

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did sit together
column13: I waited to book our seats online until the date Ryanair stated we could book our seats free a few days before we flew. The site did say the seats would be randomly allocated but I expected they would be 3 seats together. The 3 seats we could book for free were the furthest apart possible despite there clearly being rows of 3 seats together. I tried a second time and again the seats were far apart but in different locations to the previous allocation, despite it being very clear I was travelling as a single adult with 2 children aged 13. I ended up paying nearly £50 to book seats together on both flights. We travelled to Barcelona from Manchester 28/10/17 returning 02/11/2017.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 5.1.1; KFDOWI Build/LVY48F) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Silk/63.1.34 like Chrome/63.0.3239.111 Safari/537.36

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
When I booked my wife was placed on a block of three seats (at the time of booking all three seats were empty) near the front of the plane (row 5 I think).  My daughter who is 18 was placed in an aisle seat on the same row but the opposite side of the aisle.  I was booked in to a seat in row 16.

When we boarded the plane, there was still a single seat left in the block of three where my wife was sitting (as well as other free seats on the plane).  The gentleman who was sitting next to my wife swapped seats with my daughter and I moved from my seat to sit with my family.  

On the return flight my wife and daughter both had aisle seats (row 4 and row 5) whereas I was placed in row 33.  When I booked there were two seats available in one block of three and one aisle on the same row in the other block of three seats.  We could only have booked them if we paid for them.

The minimum amount it would have cost for us to book three seats together was £16 each way.  In addition, when on the flight people were told not to move seats (to sit next to family and friends) as the seating allocation was based on weight (which is a nonsense at an individual passenger level).

Ryanair are using their "random" seat allocation as means to gouge passengers for more money.  All low cost airlines are looking to achieve this either by trying to get you to pay for your seat or, like easyjet, by trying to force you to pay extra to take your carryon baggage in to the cabin despite pushing customers to forego putting  baggage in the hold.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We booked as a couple and recently flew Edinburgh to Prague with EasyJet. When checking in online we were allocated separate seats but would have had to pay extra to sit together which we did not want to do. When I looked at the seating plan online at the time of checking in there were about 90% of seats still available yet we were allocated on different rows. Once we boarded the plane it was still about 25% empty  so no need for us to have been separated. Definitely felt that they were trying to get us to pay the extra for selecting seats despite being lots of room. Glad we did not pay the extra. 
Also for this flight they were trying to get people to put their carry on into the hold yet there was room on the flight meaning there  was space in the seats and the overhead lockers. Glad we hadn’t fallen for this trick either.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 11_2_2 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/604.4.7 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.0 Mobile/15C202 Safari/604.1

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: I waited to check in on Thursday 1 February 2018 at 11.40 - the earliest time possible for our flight no. TOM 94 on the 8/2/18 at 11.40 to Punta Cana (Dominican Republic) and although I had checked the previous day, there were 6 pairs of seats remaining together, and several separate seats on the ends, that wouldn't have been too far apart.  When I checked in on the dot, there appeared to be only 2 remaining seats which they had allocated to us, which left me no option but to confirm and take them - they are seat numbers 18F and 16 C, which are not anywhere close to each other, but over on the next isle.  I then went to the return flights and there were still several pairs of seats remaining, but despite this, they offered seats apart still, so as I preferred to be sitting together on a long flight, I had no choice but to move my seat next to my husband's costing £15.50 - which wasn't as bad as having to pay £68 extra to pre-book both of our seats to ensure that we sat together each way.  When I have used Easy Jet on many occasions for short flights, they have always automatically selected seats to sit us together, even though I did not select seats and pay the extra, there was only 1 occasion when this did not happen, but they at least put us at the end of the isle on both sides, so still effectively near each other.  Although I realise that this is a chance that you take when you choose not to pay the extra (which I firmly believe is just another money making  scheme of theirs!), I do think that if seats are still available together when you wait to check-in, then it is obvious that you are travelling together and would prefer to sit together, but they have gone out of their way to sit us apart purposefully in order to gain extra money!  I really do not know why (other than wishing to pay for extra leg room, or upgraded or specific seating) why you are not automatically allocated seats at the time of booking on a first come basis.  I really feel this is just a total unhelpful money making scheme of TUI's to purposefully sit you apart when there are in fact still unallocated seats available.  I really appreciate that you are now looking into this situation - airlines should be far more helpful to passengers, after all we have a choice, I definitely feel I will think twice now before booking with them again.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.140 Safari/537.36

This has never happened with Easyjet and more recently Jet2. I suggest this is a money making scheme by Ryanair

I was asked 3 times on the outward journey and 2 times on the homeward journey if I would swop seats for others who also were seperated and I obliged each time. I am certainly suspicious of Ryanair’s seating procedures.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
My wife and myself are regular low cost airline travellers, say 10 trips to Europe each of the past 5 years, mainly with Ryanair. My recollection is that until the last couple of years were were always allocated seats together. No so now as EVERY time we book we are allocated seats in different areas of the aircraft resulting in us paying additional costs to be together. This is NOT a random allocation of seating as claimed by some airlines but a deliberate policy of separating members of the same family.  They know we book together, they know we travel together, but they still insist on not giving us adjacent seats.
Emailed Ryanair with my concerns as outlined above but received no response.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/63.0.3239.132 Safari/537.36

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: We chose randomly allocated seating and were given seats at different ends of the plane.  On the outbound flight the seat across the aisle from me was free and on the return a seat in my row of three was free. It would have cost £20 each to select seats and, as we believed the airline would try to sit us together or nearby we were willing to take the chance. This has never happened on Easyjet, or on Ryanair in the past, but their new policy and the spare seats near me, has lead me to believe they separated us deliberately. This was particularly painful as I was flying out to Portugal to cremate my mother.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (iPad; CPU OS 11_2_2 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/604.4.7 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.0 Mobile/15C202 Safari/604.1

column13:
We flew to Nurenberg  and back with Ryanair flight fr3504 I paid for priority boarding and checked in for the 2 flights 4 days before, we were both put in a aisle seat 5 rows between us, on the return flight I was put in the middle seat in row 10 seat 10e and my wife was in row 20  middle seat 20e the return flight was approximately  half full and as it was only four days  before I checked in for the flight, Ryanair knew how many people were booked on that flight and yet they could not manage to sit us together but for £ 10 per person each way they could, this is typical Ryanair fleecing  the public then charging absorbent prices on the flight for poor tea coffee and food. I feel Ryanair should be brought to task and start treating the public who pay their wages with respect, a very angry flyer
Regards
Stuart Bryan

column13: We often fly BA Business Class in Europe and EVERY time we are seated apart. I made a complaint to BA on one occasion but it was simply brushed off with some nonsense that people had paid for their seats. This was a lie because when we got on the plane I asked the people next to my partner and myself if they had paid for their seats. They hadn’t. This happened on a trip to Morocco in 2016 and again to Budapest in Dec 2017. Strangely, it hasn’t happened when we have flown long haul in either Business Class or First Class or even economy. But it seems to the norm in Short haul business Class.  The people sat next to us had also been split up.

We eventually decided that this did not amount to either a fair practice nor were willing to pay this amount and so forewent our transaction with Ryanair and decided to use Jet2 who seated us all together for no extra charge.

column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
There appears to be a very clear policy by Ryan air, brought in during the last few months to deliberately seat couples and groups apart unless they are prepared to pay extra. This has happen to me several times over the last 6 months, but never previously. In the last instance, flying back from Marrakech I had an empty seat next to me - and my partner was still seated elsewhere. 

In practice, many people get up and select new seats amongst themselves, which seems stressful, unsafe and unnecessary.  It's clearly happening to everyone who flys Ryan air, and I urge you to try and reverse this unpleasant money grabbing trend.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/63.0.3239.132 Safari/537.36

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
My partner and I were travelling to Kefalonia in September. We checked in as soon as the free check-in was available and were allocated one seat at the front of the plane and one in the middle with additional leg-room. I could see on check-in that the seats around both those seats were free but we would have to pay extra to choose seats together. When we arrived at the gate, other passengers around us were joking about how they were not sat with their partners. This was during term time, so most of the flight was couples. 

When boarding the plane, the rows surrounding me at the front of the plane was made up of split-up couples. They talked and all moved around to sit with their partners. I moved mid flight to sit with my partner in the still empty seat with extra legroom. 

As passengers were moving, Ryanair staff made an announcement to ask that passengers remain in their allocated seats as they had been allocated in order to have the correct weight distribution across the plane. How would they know this without asking our weight/height at check-in?! It was obvious to all that they had purposely split-up passengers under the same booking in order to make financial gains. 

On telling this story at work, I was not the only one to have experiences this treatment from Ryanair.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 10_3_3 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/603.3.8 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/10.0 Mobile/14G60 Safari/602.1

column13: Return flight from Valencia. All four of us were separated throughout the aircraft. My wife and I were two rows apart and on opposite sides of the aircraft. Whilst getting seated a couple of young guys found themselves split up with one seated by me  and one by my wife. Speaking to the two guys it became apparent that they booked on a single booking as indeed we had with our friends. I wrote to Ryanair asking how it was possible that both parties had been split up despite the fact that seats must have been available when at least one of the bookings was made. I received a standard response telling me that we could have paid extra if we required seats together. The point that splitting parties must be a deliberate policy was completely ignored.

column13: When using free check in with Ryanair my wife and I were allocated seats in different parts of the plane.  When I went into pay for seating there was a free seat beside my seat and my wife's seat.   This amounted to extortion of money from us, as seats were clearly available together.  We then had to pay for these seats, as we've never traveled apart in 26years together.  I have taken and have booked around 7 to 10 more flights with Ryanair and have had to pay for allocated seating, because if we don't pay, Ryanair position our seats in different parts of the plane.  As an aside I regularly use Easyjet and Aer Lingus and have always been allocated seats together at free check in.  I have felt deeply aggrieved by Ryanair's policy, which is why I sought out your website after reading this story on Yahoo.  Another money making scam which I have caught Ryanair out in, is the rebooking of flights.  They charge £40 to change flight but the price on their rebooking page was more expensive than on their normal website.  Scandalous.  I use Ryanair as they are normally competitive and cheap, but I am fed up with their charlatan practices.

Me, two male and one female friend booked a cheap budget trip to Nuremberg via Ryanair. 

We decided against paying the additional fees to sit together assuming since it was deep winter the plane would be relatively empty. 

When we boarded the plane, two people were seated at the absolute rear and two towards the front. The front two were on opposite sides, two rows apart both in middle seats while the rear two were sat one row apart on the same side, infront and behind each other. 

About ten minutes into the flight I realised the person sat next to me was speaking to the group sat around where my friend was sitting. I asked if he wanted to change knowing my friend would want to and he so happily. 

I'm almost certain they purposely gave us the absolute worst seats they possibly could to everyone who didn't reserve during that flight.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
We were booked on an Emirates flight codeshared with Qantas from Bangkok via Dubai (Emirates) and then onwards to London Heathrow (Qantas) for 14-15 January 2018.

Despite indications otherwise, I could not access paid seat selection at all for my flights at any time after booking my flights several months in advance. It seemed that, by using a codeshare flight, I could not access any of these seat selections.

During the check-in period for this trip, I noticed that my partner and I were allocated seats approximately 15-20 rows apart from one another for the Emirates flight. This was odd, as I managed to find and switch to two seats, with one behind the other on an adjacent row.  

I still could not access seat selection through Qantas for the next leg, but, by using Qantas' iOS app, I was able to find that once again we were seated several rows part. Incidentally, their website only displayed seat choices (aisle/window/no preference), not the seat allocations themselves.

I called Emirates to resolve this issue. However, the Customer Services representative couldn’t do anything to resolve the seat selections on the Emirates leg. She did however offer to put us together if we were willing to pay over £140 for two exit row seats. I complained that, having spent over £1000 for the flights already, it was unreasonable for us to be charged more than 10% extra for such a long flight. In the end, she left a note on the system that we’d prefer to be sat together, and told us just to go to the airport early. She could do nothing about the seat selection on the Qantas leg.

I called Qantas to try and rearrange the seats, but they were locked out of my booking, presumably by Emirates, and could not even see which seats I’d been assigned. As such, they could do nothing but suggest going to the airport early again.

Frustratingly, I reached out to Emirates Customer Support with a public tweet on their Twitter account (@EmiratesSupport) at 16:09 on 12 January. I received a reply by 09:20 on 13 January asking me to send them details in a private message. By 14:49 the same day, they had allocated me two seats next to one another on the Emirates flight. I could not understand why they did not do this in the first place, or why their representative had not done so over the phone.

I then arrived at the airport 6 hours early to check-in, but again Emirates said they could do nothing about the Qantas flight until I arrived in Dubai, and discussed it with the local Qantas team. However, I went straight to the Qantas desk at Bangkok Suvarnabhumi airport, and they allocated me seats next to one another straight away.

The entire process was frankly costly and frustrating, and there was no need for such poor Customer Service from mainly Emirates.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/63.0.3239.132 Safari/537.36

I complained to one of the airport managers who called a manager from Swissair to re-arrange the seating at no cost to ourselves. The Swissair manager had the attitude from hell and told me it was my fault for not paying the extra. The seating was eventually re-arranged although Swissair and Flybe were not at all happy at having to do it.
     I will never use Flybe again after this experience.

My husband and I flew with Ryanair to Carcassonne in October.  If we had chosen to pay for priority boarding we would have been able to select seats together.  We chose not to pay for this facility and when we checked in online  we were allocated by the ‘algorithm’ 2 middle seats on adjacent rows for both flights.  We were given the option to change seats to adjoining seats for a fee.  On checking this option, all the seats in both rows were free to be reserved.  In my opinion the ‘algorithm’ had purposely split us up.  We chose not to pay extra to be seated together and when talking to other passengers on the plane they too had been allocated separate seats when adjacent seats were available.

We have previously flown with Easyjet without pre-booking seats and on checking in have been allocated seats together.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/63.0.3239.132 Safari/537.36

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did not all sit together despite paying extra to do so
column13: Ryanair have changed their check-in policy so that you can't check in for free until 4 days before the flight. When we came to do that, we found that seats were fully booked down the middle of each side, leaving only window and aisle seats free. We chose to pay so we could at least sit in the same row. When we boarded, all the couples around us had been allocated seats behind each other (middle seat on one row and middle seat on the next) despite seats being free either side (e.g. the ones which we booked later). It was chaos because as everyone was boarding and trying to put bags overhead, people were also negotiating seat swaps. And that was after most of us had our cabin bags taken off us on the tarmac..

column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
This has happened to us on many occasions. We pay for flights but avoid the sitting together cost because it’s too expensive to do so. It’s not fair that when you look at the seating arrangement plan after booking, there are free seats next to you (why can’t your travelling partner sit there?) and they begin to charge extra. Here is one of my letters of complaint to Ryanair:
Hi, 
I've just tried to check myself (JM) and my mother (LM) in to our flights for free and next to each other, only, you're trying to charge me €14 for it, when the seat, according to the website and my pictures, is unoccupied next to me......

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
In my experience Ryanair definitely charge deliberately. I suspected it was the case but last year on a flight home from Tenerife, the online check in opened, within hours I went on to check in. Me and my son were sat together as he was on my lap as he was under two, yet the other two members of the party were seated at the other end of the plane despite clearly being able to see there were seats together available and empty seats next to me. I checked in (with us all scattered over the plane) and immediately called Ryanair to request to be seated together and explained I could see the seats next to me were empty. Ryanair confirmed that they could only seat the party together if we paid the charge. I explained again the seats were empty and the customer service person could just swap them. He explained he could but only if we paid as this was the policy. I had no option to pay to have us seated together.

This year we are flying with Jet2 and now we have a newborn and 2 year old and have paid an extra £60 to be seated together as we want to sit as a family. I think airlines should seat parties together prioritising individuals with minors. It wouldn't really bother me if I wasn't seated next to adults if I checked in late or made a late booking but I think it's different with minors. In my opinion it's a way if making money.

It's disgraceful.

Kind regards

Sarah

column13:
We were initially assigned seats separately (about 12 rows apart). I paid to move my partner to the seat beside the one I had been allocated to (an extra leg room seat, meaning it was expensive). 

When we arrived at the airport I was told that I had no seat on the plane as I had only paid for one of the seats to be assigned. I was then assigned a seat at the very back of the plane, meaning that after paying about £20 for us to sit together we were actually sat further apart than if I had just accepted our originally assigned seating.

My partner has a medical condition and I paid for us to sit next to each other. The staff were disinterested with our problem when we tried to discuss it. Ryanair were deliberately misleading me at every stage to get more money out of me, ruining the beginning of our holiday and leaving us both anxious and upset.

I am available for further comments if required.

column13:
The Ryanair flight to Portugal was only 50% full but despite this we were seated at approx 20 rows apart of the aircraft. 
It seemed petty, if not a form of 'punishment' not to seat us together when we booked in given there was clearly loads of room to do this.

The flight attendant stated that no one should move seats as the 'aircraft is balanced with the current seating arrangement', of course we  ignored him and moved to sit together. 

It was a similar picture on the return flight when the flight was even quieter, again we were allocated seats well apart, once again we moved.

Hopefully intervention can bring some sense to this farcical situation.

column13:
Booked Mrs H and Howe, jnr age 6 in Club (business class). BA asked for around £100 or more EACH one way to guarantee they would sit together so I paid. A clear policy on obligations on children to age X would be good. And that might mean BA has to move its premium customers on the flight. BA clearly demonstrated that they are seeking to charge extra to seat children next to adults. At £200 extra cost, I clearly asked BA what policy was - answer "we cannot guarantee". That seat selection charge is high in business. It was not an emergency exit or "premium" row.

I am a gold member with BA. Recently, Feb 18, I have given up seat in row 1 so families in transatlantic first class can be seated together! This is a feature of limited seats (24) and pre-booking of seats (by the gold/silver and people who pay) that causes families to be broken up.

column13:
In order for us to be able to print off our outbound and inbound boarding passes before we flew and to sit together we had to pay extra and reserve our seats. 

Previously we had flown with Ryanair and would not pay for reserved seating, we asked the hotel if they would print off our return boarding passes which they did, but the bar code was unreadable when we were at the check in desk and we were going to be charged £45 each for them to reprint our boarding passes. Luckily I managed to get the passes on my mobile phone and scan them in. 

Going on holiday is something we all look forward to, but these days we find the airport experience quite stressful. We are weighing our cases and hoping the scales at the airport are the same as ours and we don't have to pay for extra weight. The security process, although necessary, is also stressful and now you may have your cabin bag taken off you as you board the plane. If the bar code on your boarding pass has not printed off perfectly you may have to pay for a reprint, and you cannot print off your boarding pass until 4 days before you fly.  If you don't reserve your seats you will be separated when you board.

column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
We reported our concerns about seat bookings to the CAA on 12/12/2017 but were advised to contact Ryanair, text follows:

We have flights booked with Ryanair in February 2018 and they have advised that unless we pay for booked seats up to 60 days we will have to wait until 4 days before our flight before we can book our seats.

Advance online check-in is required up to 60 days prior to flights which we have done registering our passports etc and see no sense in having to go through the process twice to get our boarding passes.

Today, 04/02/2018 we reserved our seats and they have split us up in different rows.

We feel this is a deliberate policy followed by these airlines in order to push up the cost of air travel so why do they not adjust fares so that everyone is treated equally?

It is unfair, unjust and down right ripping of the public who should know the cost of of their travel arrangements upfront and more importantly be able to get their boarding passes when they confirm the booking.

To us this appears to be a perverse case of "Denied Boarding" between 5 and 60 days before we fly and discriminates against passengers who want to be assured that their seats are secured on the flights we have booked.

Is there nothing in the regulations that puts the passengers first irrespective of status and financial constraints in the way of obtaining boarding passes?

I checked-in myself and my wife on Sunday morning 4th February for a flight departing Stansted at 06.25 hr on Thurs 8th February bound for Budapest. 
Without wishing to pay in advance for our two seats to be together, I selected for the airline to allocate the seats. We were allocated two middle seats in different parts of the aircraft. I then checked the flight seating plan to determine the location of our seats and found there were numerous vacant seats of two or three together which had not been allocated.

column13:
Please see below for the complaint email to BA. Their response was disgracefully dismissive. Their focus is on making profit by not seating families together without paying for it.

I'm writing to complain about our flight last night from Granada, Spain to London City Airport. The flight itself was delayed by at least one hour and twenty minutes, for reasons that weren't explained to anyone, but that isn't the main reason for our complaint. 

We were also unable to check in online beforehand, though again, that isn't the main reason for our complaint. Just a mild irritant compared to the experience you then served up for us.

The primary reason for our complaint is the scandalous approach you apparently have to seating. We had booked return flights from London City to Granada in business class, mainly because the standard of your economy class service (especially from LHR/LGW) is now so bad I may as well fly Ryanair for better service at lower cost. 

For context, my wife is an extremely nervous flyer and the tickets were booked together at a cost of over £350 each.

On arrival at Granada Airport we dropped our bags at the check-in desk only to notice that we had been given separate seats, 2A and 3A. The check in agent was of no help, providing a fantastic reenactment of the "Computer says no" sketch from Little Britain. 

This was completely unacceptable on so many levels, but let me spell some of them out for you:

1. We had booked the trip with two tickets on one booking as a married couple, so why would you choose to split the seats up? Completely unacceptable.

2. There were a number of solo travellers in business class and you had chosen to split a married couple across 2A and 3A and put two solo travellers into 2B and 3B. Just what logic or justification is there for that? Again, completely unacceptable.

3. This is business class. It isn't economy, where no doubt you'd come up with some pathetic policy based excuses about seats not being guaranteed etc. However, for the amount we had paid: completely unacceptable.

4. Paid-for seat reservations should be used when a passenger fancies being nearer the front of the plane for example and is happy to pay extra to secure this. We shouldn't need to pay for seat reservations to ensure two married individuals sit together on a flight they've booked together. Completely unacceptable.

Whilst we're on the subject, please let your value-destroying Chief Executive know that trying to charge passengers in business class crazy amounts to pre-book seats is tantamount to a budget airline. Is this really British Airways? ("To fly, to rip passengers off at every possible turn"? I digress again.)

My wife is an extremely nervous flyer, so had we stuck with our allocated seats and sat separately, then we would have had to walk off the flight. On boarding the aircraft we asked the lead stewardess what could be done, with my wife terrified, and helpfully she spoke to passengers in 2B and 3B asking them if they could switch seats. Reluctantly one agreed. 

However, we were made to look and feel like the awkward disruptive passengers causing delays and chaos on an already heavily delayed flight. I do not pay you £350 per ticket to be treated like a pariah in business class because of a problem entirely of your own making.

My wife's anxiety levels are already sky high before a flight and I'd therefore like to understand why you think it is permissible for you to utterly demolish any relaxation achieved whilst on holiday and cause so much additional damage to my wife's health as a result of your incompetence. She was extremely upset and panicked during the delay and throughout the flight, heightened because she thought she may have to sit alone.

In light of this, what I'm not expecting in response is a ridiculous boilerplate customer service response. I'm also not interested in hearing (as I do so regularly in the press) about how your chief executive apparently isn't running a once good airline into the dust through his own quest for cost savings at the expense of quality of service.

I want to understand, in a format you'd be comfortable being shared on BBC Watchdog, Which magazine and the like, as to why you think it is appropriate to split married couples up on a flight for no justifiable reason whatsoever. I'm then interested in what you're going to do about the huge anxiety, anguish and stress caused, so I can explain to my wife that of course you do have her health and safety interests and quality customer service at the forefront of your approach. Whilst I don't want to use BA at all, my wife seems to like you. Hard to fathom, I know.

In the interests of balance, the stewardess on board was helpful and the crew did their best to sort things out. No thanks to the corporate policies, systems and processes that you've designed to "serve" your passengers. Sometimes I'd hope your corporate vision would actually translate into  something meaningful rather than being words on a website (that your value-destroying Chief Executive can hide behind).

column13:
This accompanied the link :- If you think you've deliberately been given separated seats by Ryan air (or others), read on :

The civil aviation authority are having an investigation into airlines deliberately seating customers apart to make them pay for seats. They are after feedback. If you fancy helping them challenge Ryan Air, the link is at the bottom and the text below is what I sent - you could perhaps rephrase it a bit but keep the message...

"There appears to be a very clear policy by Ryan air, brought in during the last few months to deliberately seat couples and groups apart unless they are prepared to pay extra. This has happen to me several times over the last 2 years  but never previously.  We have seen parents with young children a allocated  separate seats.

In practice, many people get up and select new seats amongst themselves, which seems stressful, unsafe and unnecessary. It's clearly happening to everyone who flies Ryan air, and I urge you to try and reverse this unpleasant money grabbing trend."

column13:
I have a medical condition (Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome) which is an inherited condition that affects spine, joints gut and blood vessels. Many people with my condition are unable to fly. However if I manage it carefully, I am able to fly. 
I have orthostatic hypotension-even when seated my blood pressure can drop-elevating my legs (if necessary putting my knees on my husband's lap or against the side wall of the plane) resolves the problem. If I cannot do this, I  develop dizziness, headaches, difficulty in thinking, sweating, nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.
On longer flights (eg over 2 hours), the slipped/fused discs in my neck cause severe pain. Again, resting  and supporting my head and neck against the side wall of the plane makes an enormous difference to my pain levels.
To manage this I request a window seat (anywhere on the plane-I don't mind) with my husband next to me. I am usually asked to pay significant sums of money for both of us to ensure a wall/window seat. When I explain my disability, the airlines are generally uninterested and say they can only support people who are deaf/blind or in a wheelchair, and if I need assistance with my medical problems I must pay the supplements. On one occasion, travelling to the USA  they quoted me around £340 return extra -this was just for one leg of the flight each way in economy class-had we reserved a seat on each leg of the journey it would have been much more. 
Only occasionally are airlines sympathetic to this problem and will allocate me a seat window/wall seat . My daughter who inherited the same disorder experiences the same difficulties on flights as me.

column13: I have booked to fly with British Airways in September 2018 LHR to Boston. As a treat I booked business class for my wife and I. It was only during the final stages did I discover that to choose a seat would cost from  £77 each per seat each way. Three years ago this was free. I purposely booked early to guarantee us sitting together. I booked the flights but not seats, too expensive. I then made contact with BA (Which was very difficult) to query the charges. BA advised me that they were now charging to pre book seats due to a customer survey conducted by BA in which customers allegedly said they would pay to reserve seats. The operator could not guarantee that my wife and I would sit together if I did not pre book and just accepted allocation from what was left at check in. I queried the cost and the operator was lost for words. I have now paid in total £354  to book in fear that we would not be able to sit together - I think this is a ridiculous amount especially considering the initial cost of the flights.

column11: We did sit together
column13:
What an absolute shower Ryanair are!  
My wife and I were flying from Prestwick to Malaga (return) at the end of August/early September.  I decided not to pay for the seating, but to wait until check-in opened a few days before the flights and therefore not having to pay without having to pay.  Despite there being plenty of available seats together at check-in, Ryanair's algorithm is deliberately set up in such a way that you have as much chance as winning the lottery as sitting together.  My wife and I were allocated seats at opposite ends of the plane for outward/return flights, and I was basically forced to pay for sitting together.  I phoned Ryanair to complain, but needless to say they were not interested and admitted their algorithm was not set up in a way to have people sitting together - this is purely to rip-off their customers.  There is absolutely no other reason for their algorithm being set the same as other airlines.  About time the authorities should be clamping down on such immoral business practices adopted by Ryanair, or others who do the same.

The flight(s) are on Wed, 7th Feb, 2018.  My granddaughter, aged 14, needs to get to northern Spain.  She would be allowed to fly alone on easyjet to Bilbao, but we chose to fly Ryanair.  This means that I have to fly to Santander with her (from Edinburgh) then get back on the same plane and fly straight back to Edinburgh, a total of about 5 hours.  I have just checked in and she has been put in row 6 and I in row 33.  Clearly Ryanair wants me to fly with her since they won't let her fly alone, but it's not so important to them that they put us anywhere near each other.  If she were 4 I would pay to sit near her, but she's not worried about sitting apart from me.  Why do I need to go there (and back) at all?
E Alcock

Although we were both on the same PNR with the same surname and checked in, in the same transaction, my wife and I were allocated separate seats for both the outbound and inbound flights.  This is a deliberate function of the check in and seating profile to force those wanting to sit together to pay to do so.   Once upon a time passengers such as my wife and me would most certainly have been seated together.   It is clear that airlines have discovered a way of forcing their computer system (in this case Navitair) to act in this way so they can claim it is "random"   Nothing in the computer world is "random" unless written to be so.   This is a clear breach of the regulation requiring airlines to show the full price as the headline price.
No complaint was made to Jet2 as I thought is to be a waste of time.

Ryanair offer bookable seats for a charge in addition to the ticket price.  We have never taken up this offer and let them allocate seats when we check in.  For the first time in 20 plus flights we were allocated seats in different rows, previously having always been allocated seats together.  
On boarding the plane we found there were spare seats in the rows we were allocated so could easily have been allocated seats together.  There were many other passengers in the same position on our flight so after take off there was a mass swapping of seats.
I said to my wife at the time I suspected this was deliberate in order to encourage paying the extra for seats up front.
Have flown with other low cost airlines including Easy Jet and Jet2 who operate similar seating systems and have not  experienced the same with them though I  suspect they will do the same if Ryanair get away with this.

column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13: Myself and a work colleague have been travelling between Bristol and Dublin on Ryanair for about 4 years, once every 1 or two months. I always book our flights and check in online and until May 2017 whenever I did so we were always allocated 2 seats next to each other. We never paid extra for it. Then, when we travelled in May 2017 we were allocated 10B and 30E, 2 middle seats, 20 rows apart. I went to the section of the site to choose seats and at the time 10A and 10C were both available so we could have been allocated 2 seats next to each other. We didn't pay, we just sat apart. Now, every time we fly, if we don't pay for specific seats, where we sit depends on how close to the flight time that we check in. If we check in as early as we can we get 2 middle seats separated. If we check in as late as possible we end up in either an aisle seat or a window seat as all the middle seats have been allocated. Every flight now starts with passengers trying to negotiate with each other so that they can sit with their friends or family and that again causes delays, frustration and in some cases anger. Our feeling is that if making money is the issue, Ryanair should simply charge £5 more per seat and allocate groups of seats together. Nobody would complain about that. Ryanair's "policy" may not have changed but their seat allocation algorithm definitely has.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
As part of a British Airways holiday my wife and I had booked two business class seats to Tel Aviv on a flight leaving on 15 January.  As a 'Bronze' Executive Club member I am entitled to reserve seats on BA flights without charge a week before departure. When I sought to do so, however, I was astonished to find that my wife and I had been allocated entirely separate seats in different rows of the cabin. According to the BA system there were no other seats available.

When I eventually managed to make contact by phone with a BA member of staff I said that this was highly unsatisfactory and  explained that my wife and I are in our late 60s and absolutely did not want to be seated apart on a 5 hour flight. The member of staff, while polite, said that there was absolutely nothing that she could do. Her only suggestion was that we try to get our seats reallocated at check in at the airport. All attempts to speak to a more senior BA person proved fruitless.

We did in the end manage to sit together after explaining the position at check in but the whole experience was a very stressful one which took much of the gloss off what was meant to be a very special holiday. I think it quite bizarre that we were not allocated seats together at the outset given that we had made a single booking with identical surnames from which it would have been self-evident that we were a couple.

column13:
Our family has flown with Finnair having seats next to each other dozens of times and never needed to book seats.

Ryanair used to allocate consecutive seats too in the past, but the last three flights they have separated our family. My wife is always seated next to our 5 years old son and me half a plane away from them. It seems to us like a recent policy change aimed to sell the seats twice and we refuse to pay.

On the last flight from Dublin we missed the bus transportation to the terminal because of this.

I have a hearing impairment which makes all intercom announcements completely unintelligible to me (I depend on my wife to keep me informed).

We have not confronted Ryanair about this, we very much doubt they would listen.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; Lenovo YT3-X90F Build/MMB29M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.137 Safari/537.36

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
We fly several times a year  on easyjet and Ryanair to Nice and Athens.  Last and this year Ryanair have always sat us separately and I believe this is a new policy.  On 1 Feb 2018, I paid for us to sit together as we had been sat apart only to find there were 145 empty seats on the plane and everyone got up and moved to empty rows.  Easyjet, in my opinion, still seat people together.  Ryanair are aware of this as now there is a new announcement asking people to remain in their designated seats which they never did before.  
I feel as long as Ryanair accept that this is their new policy it is ok.  For the last 4 Ryanair flights booked we have always been sat at either end of the plane and one of us is always in a premium seat and one right at the back which leads me to believe that they want me to purchase a premium seat.  On board they have to now ask people to move to overwing exit seats as nobody wants to pay for them.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (iPad; CPU OS 9_3_5 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/601.1.46 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/9.0 Mobile/13G36 Safari/601.1

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
When checking in online, the 'random' seat allocation was clearly weighted to separate people and to pick low cost seats. 
On a previous flight with Ryanair the same thing happened, and after the flight it turned out that the people we sat next to were a couple that were also separated from each other.
On the most recent flight, I was moved to an emergency exit window seat because someone had 'stolen' seat elsewhere and passengers were shuffled around. Whilst sitting there, I imagined exiting the plane in an emergency and thinking about waiting on the wing for my wife to come through, torn between her safety and the safety of other passengers. Irresponsible thoughts, I know.
As it turned out, the plane performed two go arounds at MAN before being diverted to BHX due to strong winds. I later learned that she genuinely thought she was going to die. Feeling guilty about not paying the extra to sit with her now.

No doubt Ryanair will be secretly updating their backend seat allocation code and we'll magically see true random seat allocations. The only way you'll prove anything is to get to airports and survey passengers as they board and use the statistics to show patterns for 'random' seats.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 8.0.0; A0001 Build/OPD3.170816.023) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.137 Mobile Safari/537.36

column13:
Booked WT+ BA;  returning from San Francisco, at on line check in 24 hours before flight had been allocated seats apart. No two seats together  appeared to be free.  When eventually boarded and seated, the seat next to me was free. This had not shown on system at check in and caused 24hours of upset of believing would spend long flight separated.  Noticed on seat allocation system that the only seats appearing available to change with were all single seats and this was at the earliest time one could check in to change allocation of seats.
Being told by TA that if want to sit together need to book seats together,  cost me £120.00 on a recent Emirates flight to Japan,. Never used to be like this, airlines, even the big companies,   changed systems in 2016 to fee for seats together.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered about doing so (e.g. it was a short flight, we didn’t mind sitting apart etc)
column13: I was flying with my husband.  I didn't pay for the seats together  because we spend plenty of time together, neither of us are nervous air passengers, and  they were short flights.  I was also aware that it was a new policy for budget airlines to put you in seats far apart in order to encourage you to pay the extra.  I didn't pay because I thought it was a greedy and unfair policy but accept that by flying with cheap airlines you just have to accept unpleasant hidden extras and zero customer care.  However during the flight there was turbulence and I was upset to think that if we crashed we wouldn't be able to comfort each other.  I therefore decided that in future I would probably pay the extra to have  my family nearby even if I think it is a cynical and exploitative development on the part of the airlines.

column13:
We were flying to Johannesberg on Virgin, two people on the same booking reference and identical itinerary. Our seats allocated at on line check the day before departure were in different rows and opposite sides of the plane. This was in spite of several rows of seats towards the rear having banks of 3 seats together available. We thought we had been unnecessarily seated apart, and suspect this was deliberate (but we can't prove that of course).
Worse the on line check in allowed us to move one passenger into the bank of 3 free seats but was unable to process moving the second passenger to the adjacent seat. We don't know why. So we sat apart for a flight of 11 hours.

column13:
When organising the boarding passes our seats were 'randomly allocated' which meant none of us would have been together.  My brother recovering from a stroke would have been next to strangers without assistance.  I would have thought after asking for and achieving wheelchair assistance to the plane he would have been allocated a seat at the front with his partner.

To achieve a satisfactory seating arrangement my only option was to pay for two front seats at £20-00 each way per person for my brother and partner and then two seats further back for my wife and I at about £7-00

Previously 'random allocated' seats on Ryanair usually gave us seats together.  This is another way of keeping face value prices low and charging for 'extras' which should not be extras

Internet sales and then automated check in etc means there’s hardly ever any opportunity to speak to a real human being about it which doesn’t help either. You end up buying seats just in case.

column11: We did sit together
column13:
It was a Lufthansa flight from LHR to FRA.

I paid £16 extra at booking time to choose seats with extra 
legroom.

At the gate, my wife was told that she couldn't sit in the 
booked seat because "aircraft change - the seat is now in
first class".

I wasn't told this.

The cabin crew insisted we couldnt sit in those seats despite the
fact that they were not in first class, as we had been told at the gate.

We had to sit right at the back of the plane, and were last to be served
food and drink.

On returning to London I asked Lufthansa for a refund of the seat 
allocation fee and they refused.

I escalated the matter and they refused again.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did sit together
column13: Upon completing online check-in (almost as soon as it opened), our group of 5 was allocated seats for free, but they were all in completely different parts of the aircraft (e.g. one individual was the very back row whereas another was in row 5). Ryanair then gave us the option to pay extra to choose our seats, at which point it became clear that there were, in multiple parts of the aircraft, 5 clear seats next to each other that could have been allocated to us for free in the first place. Unlike when we have previously flown with Ryanair, it was clear to us that they were purposefully splitting passengers up, rather than allocating groups together where possible. We paid the extra fee and did not complain to the airline, but would not fly with them again. Compare with Easyjet, who will allocate everyone together for free where possible, but still give the option to pay to choose specific seats if desired. This is a lot fairer.

However 3 months later we were advised that we had been transferred to a later flight that day, and then found out that only 3 of us were still together in the area originally booked and the rest had been allocated to areas in the main body of the aircraft.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13: We fly with Ryanair approx 10 times per year and have done for over 10 years (usually just husband and self).  Until the Spring of 2017, we were invariably allocated adjacent seats, without paying extra.  After that time we have invariably been allocated seats many rows apart.  I heard a Ryanair spokesperson on the radio saying they had not changed their policy.  I do not believe this.  At least, they must have changed their algorithm for allocating seating.  They shot themselves in the foot when they made this change. Because as soon as passengers get on board, those not sitting together try to swap seats.  It's like musical chairs on some flights.  Then if passengers succeed in swapping seats and have already put their cabin bags in the overhead lockers, they start trying to move their bags.  Result - chaos.  Ryanair had a much publicised initiative to be more customer friendly 2 or 3 years ago, when they started allowing a handbag as well as a cabin bag.  This seating allocation procedure infuriates customers!
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_11_6) AppleWebKit/604.5.6 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.0.3 Safari/604.5.6

column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: All 6 seats booked for myself, my husband and our 4 children were allocated apartincluding my 9 year old daughter. It was costing another £160 to pays for seats for us all and after paying almost £2100 for the flights and baggage we just couldn't afford it. I ended up paying to sit with my 9 year old but the rest of the family were separated. This had a negative impact on our holiday as my children were upset about sitting with strangers and worried about this again for the return flight. It's obviously a money making scheme and was blatantly done deliberately with nothing random about it.

column13: New booking with BA travel to California 1-17 May 2108. Online purchase denied option of seat selection until ticket purchase completed and paid. Then as separate process seat allocation exorbitantly priced £49 per seat, but by then committed. I am 78  and my wife 74, I need to visit the toilet frequently so an aisle seat is paramount, my wife needs easy access. It would be stressful not to be seated together or have appropriate seats. This appears new BA booking process as previous years we could choose in the ticketing process and the cost was far less. The uncertainty having to wait until the flight opened to secure the seats would be highly stressful and most unfair. We were forced to accept additional hidden costs of nearly £200.  Your study has a focus on those with children I suggest it should additionally consider elderly and incapacitated. Iam disgusted with BA and would in future consider looking elsewhere.

column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13: We were travelling from London Gatwick to Las Vegas for our honeymoon in June 2012.  We booked the flights through Thomas Cook in a store. We were told that our seats were together in row J and we were not advised that we needed to check in online for the flight. We realised that we weren't seated together when we arrived at the airport. I had been upgraded to business class on the upper deck and my husband was seated on the lower deck! They managed to move my seat to the lower deck but I was then seated 10 rows away from my husband. The woman that was seated in front of him was also separated from her family so she kindly swapped seats with me. It wasn't exactly a great start to our honeymoon and the attitude of the virgin staff was absolutely appalling. I will never travel with them again. We now always pay to select our seats as we're travelling with young children.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We've regularly flown with Ryanair and always been sat together in the past - within the last year there was a clear change where on every flight we were separated - even though their marketing department denies there has been any change in policy.

On one flight I was in a group of six, and we had all been placed on our own in the middle seat in different areas of the plane. 

I've seen many people negotiating with others to do swaps, so groups are sat together again. I successfully did this once.

Ryanair make announcements over the tannoy when people do this, telling people that they must sit in their allocated seat.

I find the ambiguity as to when you can and can't sit together, depending upon whether you pay, infuriating.

I also think that there is a safety issue. What if there was a problem on the plane? Loved ones would be wanting to rush up and down the aisles to be with each other. I think that it should be compulsory for groups to be sat together unless it is logistically impossible, and even then, sub-groups should be grouped together whenever possible, rather than split up individually.

column13:
This is a related issue to the group seating.

When I travel on BA, I consistently choose to sit in an aisle seat. Obviously, BA knows this from its records. EVERY time they automatically allocate me a seat, they give me a window seat. Without fail.

Now this COULD be because more people like window seats than like aisle seats. But it could also be because they know I prefer aisle seats and am therefore more likely to pay to move seats if allocated a window seat.

I urge you to ask them, and other airlines, if such practices go on.

Kind regards

Anthony Rice.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We were allocated seats 24 hours before flying and even though my son was only 9 years old, his Dad, myself and my son were allocated 3 middle seats in different rows.  When I phoned to ask why my son was expected to sit on his own, I was told that there was nothing that could be done until we boarded the plane.

I had heard that children under 12 should always be seated with a parent.  Is this not true?  You have to give the ages of children when you book, so it is not a case of not knowing his age.  I was prepared (although dreading) having to sit separately from my husband, but had assumed that one of us would be able to sit with our son.  There were also plenty of spare seats on the plane - and in fact the very nice cabin crew sorted us a row where we could all sit together, without having to move anyone.  So this was not an issue of space either.  

Splitting people just to ensure you get the extra money for the seating is disgusting and wrong, and even more so when there are children involved.  Holidays are expensive enough without the added unnecessary expense.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
-My email to Ryanair (12/7/17):

Hi,

I'm just wondering why I can book flights for 2 people but unless I pay extra for allocated seating, Ryanair's algorithm will ensure that we're seated as far apart as possible.

I really thought you'd moved past the price gouging in recent years. While price is one of the main factors I consider when choosing a flight, this just feels remarkably petty after I'd paid £360 for flights.

-Their response on 13/7/17:
We refer to your online enquiry dated 12th July 2017.

Please be advised that is customer’s choice to pay or not for a seat. We are not trying to force people to pay for reserved seats. We are very happy to facilitate any customer who wants a free of charge random seat but we are also going to do our best to facilitate customers who are willing to pay for a reserved seat (usually window or aisle) which start from £2.

We trust that the above has been of assistance.

-My response on 13/7/17:
Thank you for the prompt reply. 

As I noted in my email, it's entirely your decision how much you charge and the extras that you charge for. I haven't come across any other airline that "randomly" allocates middle seats at opposite ends of the plane when you check in 3 days before the flight but maybe I've just been lucky.

As I've also noted in my email, I will factor this additional cost of £15-20 into any price comparisons with other airlines. I've checked my return flight from Dublin and it will cost £4 per seat. My next flight with Ryanair is in August and it's going to cost me £3.75 per seat each way.

While you clearly don't agree, this is a stealth charge, similar to your mark up on credit card payment fees and the previous tactic of automatically charging for extras (eg. insurance) unless it was unselected.

Their response on 26/7/17:
We refer to your online enquiry dated 13th July 2017.

Whilst we sympathise with your view, we regret that our position as set out in the letter dated 13/07/2017 remains unaltered. 

We trust that the above has been of assistance.

column3: Within the last month
column11: None of these
column13:
Outbound flight was fine we were in Row 11 - seats D&E Club World. F
Inbound flight - at check-in we were allocated Row 3 - seats G & K.  We were in Club Lounge, San Jose, Costa Rica for approx 4 hours with no issues raised.
At embarkation, my wife was tannoyed and a very aggressive male ground staff member grabbed her boarding card from me, stopping me from taking a picture of it as proof.  We were separated for the whole flight me in Row 3, my wife in Row 11.  I kept asking staff to assist her with seat controls as she could not operate them, very poor service.
My choice of meal was removed from my table as I waited for the trolley to move and given to another person.
Flight supervisor logged my complaints and I have received an acknowledgement of that but no further action taken since Jan 19th.  It was our 52nd anniversary holiday and we were both very upset.
Flight cost was £4500+ and I am looking for some form of compensation as we are Executive club members.  I might add that the original cost quoted by the executive club was £8000 which I declined and booked our tickets online myself with BA, computer system is an absolute shambles.

column13: When we booked with ryanair on a flight from east midlands to malaga in january this year the plane was almost empty according to their seating plan. However, when we chose random seat allocation we were given 1 seat in row 5 and the other in row 28 even though 85% of the seats were still empty. The only way we could sit together was to pay between £15-£21 for one of us to move to the seat next to the other. I dont understand why we could not have been seated next to each other in the first place other than for ryanair to deliberatly force one of us to pay the extra to enable us to sit together. This sort of thing needs to be stopped it is daylight robbery

column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
My wife and I have been flying with Ryanair for about 5 years.  We always made sure that we checked in online 4 days prior to departure (previously 2 weeks) and until May 2017 would always be allocated seats together.

On 4 May 2017 we flew with Ryanair from Manchester to Lanzarote.  We had checked in online on 30 April and we're seated together.  However, when we came to check-in online 4 days prior to our return flight on 25 May, we we're seated at different ends of the plane.  It is our belief that during our visit to Lanzarote, Ryanair's online check-in software was reprogrammed to deliberately seat us apart.

We flew with Ryanair again in September/October 2017  and we're seated at opposite ends of the plane on both the outbound and inbound flights.  After checking in online for both flights, a screen appeared offering the opportunity for us to pay extra to sit together.

We've since booked flights for September/October 2018 with Ryanair and during the booking process were prompted to pay additional fees to sit together.

I am convinced that Ryanair's booking software has an algorithm built in to deliberately seat groups apart then offer them the chance to pay additional fees to sit together.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: My wife & our 17 year old daughter flew from LHR to Tokyo on BA0007, 18 July 2017, for a holiday. We treated ourselves to Business Class flights. We knew we could pay to get allocated seats, but at £67 each were reluctant to do so, and we could not believe that BA would split up a family in Business Class. But it did - allocating 3 different seats in 3 separate rows. The system would not allow me to check in online the day before either, potentially choosing seats free at that point. Our travel agent rang BA but it said it couldn't do anything to get us sitting together. At LHR the check in desk couldn't do anything either except call the back office to try before we boarded. The woman at the gate was apologetic but also could do nothing. She did however say "since the new system came in none of us have been able to do changes like we could before". The chief steward on the plane said it was "outrageous" that a family wasn't seated together.  But he spent 5 minutes reorganising people and got 2 of us sitting together at least. I suppose once all seats are "buyable" there is not much scope left for the airline managing allocations after lots are bought. Assignments would have to be fixed before opening the rest for sale.  BA staff were very sympathetic, but had no means of helping compensate for "the system". We will now avoid flying BA whenever possible, and tell everyone it is now a budget airline of the worst kind even for premium travellers.

We called up Vueling to register our special needs case as part of a group of 7. That was placed on the booking. However despite the plane maps online showing all seats were available, we were split across three back rows (2 in one row, 2 on the opposite side, 2 in another row an 1 on their own).

I called up immediately and was told that it is is allocated at random (even though the plane was showing all seats for free. i was presented with the only option of paying for seats with a special needs case where at £4 per head - and was able to get to get from rows 39 and 40 to Row 25 ABCD and Rows 26 ABC

With another trip to barbados with Virgin, we could get a free seat allocation for the specila needs case plus one other but not for the other three memebrs of thre party which included a 9 year old

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
My travel has exclusively been with one other person - my wife. My experience is that airlines actively make sure we have to sit apart if we don't pay the extra to sit together.  The last time this happened we booked a Tui holiday to Fuerteventura, with a Thomas Cook flight, which Thomas Cook subbed out to an airline we had never heard of.  As a result the on-line booking facility was confusing / not available so we didn't book seats.
At check in we asked for seats together and were told there were none, and that we would have to be across the aisle, but were then told even this wasn't possible. We asked to pay to 'upgrade' to sit together but told we couldn't.
Airlines take booking and money months in advance. It is diabolical to charge that airlines charge extra to sit next to a travelling companion. They would be better offering a reduction to those those who are nor bothered. 
My wife is adamant airlines make sure you are split up if you don't pay, and I now agree.
Once we were split up when there was two complete sets of 3 seats free.
Another time we were split on the outbound, but it was no problem to sit together on the inbound
Our experience is resentment at having to pay so much to sit together, or spoil the travel experience by sitting apart.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 7.0; SM-T713 Build/NRD90M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.137 Safari/537.36

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We booked a flight from Gatwick to Malta return and on both occasions we experienced issues with the way Ryanair randomly selects our seats. We paid for 1x adult per 1 under 12. But still, we encountered issues with the allocated seats. 
Their system put an under 18 teenager in a seat near the emergency exit, both legs of our travel. And there was complete chaos when some other passengers are actually sitting where our group with children were suppose to seat. Stewards and stewardess were obviously pressured and having a hard time re arranging seats. 

Definitely  we feel that RyanAir, as though information were available, consciously made their system in a way that will make their passengers have 2nd thoughts of booking and paying for a confirmed seat.

Disappointing is an understatement and we welcome this investigation by the government.

column13:
My husband I very frequently fly with Ryanair. Usually this is glasgow to Dublin and return, to visit family. We have flown this route on a regular basis for the last few years. We have also flown other routes.
Prior to he introduction of charges for choosing seats together we found that we were pretty well always seated together. Since the introduction of charges we have never been together, even when there has been an empty seat next to one of us, or when the plane ( recently) had only 90 passengers.  
If you opt not to pay to choose a seat you are nearly always allocated a middle seat, even when others are available 
I cannot believe that the random allocation ( as claimed by Ryanair) has produced such different results since the introduction of charges!





seated together her

It can easily be make out that Ryanair was doing to make more money as Ryanair knows that group prefer to seat together. 
We thought it may be one of the case. so we didn't do checkout at that time. We thought if we do it later. those preferred seats may be allocated to us later. but in vain. Sadly we all needed to seat away from each other in both journeys.  Hope CAA will take some strict legal actions against Ryanair. Thank you very much for hearing from us.

Checked in on line for a party of 4 and were allocated seats opposite ends of the plane.
I sat next to a woman in row 33 whilst my husband was seated next to her husband in row 17.
We just swapped with each other so we could sit with our spouses. Other party members not so fortunate and sat apart.
It is totally stupid that Ryanair split both all parties up in such a manner.
From on line check in up to day of departure I made dummy bookings to see how the allocation of seats were doing. It showed that everyone was being allocated a middle seat. This way it left seats available to pay to sit next to a companion if you wanted to fork out money, usually inflated because you don't choose to do so at time of booking.

column13: Party of 16 flew to Corfu with TUI 2017. Some of the party wanted to book seats but others didn’t and they would only do pre seat bookings for the whole party and not just one family. When I looked at the seats we had been allocated we had been split up, it wasn't to bad for most as they were in rows of three so we moved around. 1 of our party was 5 rows away on his own and 2 of our children age 11 and 15 had a spare seat in the middle of them ? Any one could have been allocated that seat this could be unsafe for children. I spoke to TUI and they said they couldn’t do anything and we would have to pay to get the member of our party into the seat in the middle of our children, I did not pay I had to ask the person who was allocated the seat of  he would mind swapping seats so their father could sit in the middle of them, luckily he didn’t mind. I was worried about the child welfare issue,TUI obviously wasn’t.

column13:
I have had both positive and negative experiences over the years. The situation below is about an up and coming flight.

We paid €27 for the return leg of some flights to Palma later this month with Jet2. At the time of booking in October the price to select our seat on top was €12.23 pp and we declined to do so.  The day before checkin opened, after several reminders, the price has risen to €15.54 pp and yet the € exchange rate hasn’t varied by 25% in that time. We have been allocated 3 x F seats (Window) 4 and 7 rows apart despite there being groups of 3 available when we checked-in online. In one case seat E was still available to new bookings! We’re not bothered on a 2.5 hour flight but felt the cost was not justified against the price of the flight.

column13: We are a group of friends who travel together regularly for European weekend breaks. We use Ryanair often, albeit reluctantly, as they have more destinations to chose from. We always used to be seated together although we refuse to pay  extra to do so. The last few trips we have taken we have been seated all over the plane with none of us seated together for either leg of the trip. On the last trip we took we were ‘randomly’ seated in 4 different locations but there were 2 seats available next to one of the group and one seat next to another so it wasn’t because the seats were previously booked. Passengers were swapping amongst each other to be able to sit with their travel companions. I think asking people to pay for seats together is another airline money making scam.

column13: We went to book in online and were given seats away from each other one at the front and one at the back. My husband had booked assistance and I needed to be sat with him.
