column13: I think that people feel 'coerced' to pay extra to sit together by the airlines. On holiday flights there was never really a need to pay extra unless you required extra legroom seats. Now, however due to the fact that so many people are paying this extra charge and choosing their seats in advance, anyone making a late booking may not have any choice in where they sit as the remainder are randomly spread around the plane. Previously the airline just filled the plane on a first come first served basis on check in, meaning that people travelling together were allocated seats together when checking in. The pay for your seat charge is just another means for holiday companies in particular to squeeze some extra money from the masses.

column3: More than 12 months ago, but within the last 2 years
column11: We did sit together
column13:
We booked a package holiday by 'phone from Glasgow to Spain with Jet2 in the schools holidays period 2016 - for 4 adults and 2 young children.
When I made the booking the sales advisor indicated that there were six seats available together outward and return, and did I want to pay extra to reserve these seats ?
I asked why I was required to pay this supplement as the seats were unreserved at the time of booking.
The reply was to the effect that this was the procedure to guarantee seats together. I again asked why unreserved could not be allocated at time of booking free of charge and received a similar answer. 
I declined to pay more and escalated the issue by email to Stephen Heapy CEO of Jet2.
He delegated one of his staff to answer and I posed the same question and again received a non commital response.
I rephrasedthe complaint as "why is there not a first come, first served" policy - which once more was met by an evasive explanation of the company policy, rather than addressing the substantive point at issue.
In the end Jet2 allocated seats together without further cost as a goodwill gesture.
The following Easter I booked another package holiday for the same party from Jet2 and emailed Stephen Heapy to request another similar complimentary offer, which was forthcoming.
Obviously it pays to challenge policies which are fundementally flawed and morally indefensible.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; WOW64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/52.0

column13: We returned yesterday 4th Feb from Finland on a TUI Crystal ski flight and despite paying £30 for pre booked return seats together my husband and I were not seated next to each other but across an isle in  offset seats. I complained to Crystal this evening but they said together means behind or across but we were neither behind nor across. We were surrounded by couples who hadn't paid extra but were seated next to each other. They said we should have phoned to prebook the seats but this information was not on my confirmation or invoice or itinery or ticket. The information just said pre book return seats and not phone to book. I checked on line but the information given was that seats are not bookable on line but will be allocated as check in. I feel I have paid for a service which I did not receive and will put my complaint to Crystal in writing. I have always booked seats using a locator but Crystal confirmed this facility is not available on their TUI airline like it is to quote them on British Airways, Air Canada, Virgin Atlantic, Eastjet, Ryan Air. The system is confusing and misleading. I fully support that passengers with young children and special needs must always take priority but this was not an issue on my flight it was just poorly handled.

My friend is a nervous flyer. To enable us to sit together, my granddaughter and I had to be moved from the seats we had been allocated, by them, to a part of the plane which is for passengers who don’t have children with them and they wanted to charge me again when I had paid six pound, compulsory payment at time of booking. After an arguement on the phone we got sat together by paying for the 3 remaining passengers and not being charged again for myself and my grandaughter.
This happened recently on a Thomas Cook flight where everyone was arguing about not being sat together, the outcome was an hour delay. This may not seem much but on a day trip to Lapland at over £950 for 2 of us,  it’s a catastrophe. It’s a shambles and a disgrace causing mayhem.  I hope something can be done to stop this as it’s just another way of exploiting the paying passengers.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
I felt that all the passengers that booked together but didn't pay for allocated seats were deliberately separated. Some passengers sat together regardless of the fact they were separated so I actually had to find another seat elsewhere. Once the flight was underway quite a few people requested politely  to other passengers if they would mind moving so they could all try to be closer to relatives or friends.
I enjoyed talking to different people on the trip but it seemed a deliberate ploy by the airline to teach us a lesson for not paying the fee. Really what difference does it make to the airline. The only thing that happened was a potential costly delay while passengers tried to swap seats before the plane took off.

column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We did sit together
column13:
We paid to sit together however the cabin crew moved around the cabin asking passengers, us included, to move in order to accommodate a woman and her child who had not paid for allocated seating. 
We refused the request as we had paid £70 for the privilege of being seated together on a 12 hour flight. Other passengers also refused.
The outcome was that a husband and wife on the same row as us were ordered by the captain to sit apart to accommodate the non paying woman and her child, even though they had paid to sit together.
The captain feared that we would lose our take-off slot if the matter was not resolved immediately. 
The couple were distressed and other passengers disgusted on their behalf.
The couple were given an address to complain to, and complimentary drinks for the inconvenience.

I did not report my concerns to the airline as I didn’t expect they would have done anything about it without us having paid the extra charge.

column13: Usually pay to guarantee seating together. I'd like to think airlines book seats methodically in numerical and row order as bookings come in which means majority of groups are sat next to each other  (or at least across an aisle or row behind ) meaning a seperation of a group was minimal. column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
Of all the years I have flown with Ryanair, I have checked in at the earliest opportunity and I have ALWAYS  been seated with my travel companion as part of the 'random allocation' process without having to pay extra. 

However when I checked in for my flight (FR5994 from London Stansted to Madrid due to depart on 11th November 2017) at 530am on the earliest day I could do so, I found my friend and I were sat at opposite ends of the plane. I could see the plane was literally empty, so why wouldn't Ryanair ordinarily try and sit those customers travelling together next to each other as they have done previously. This change in algorithm appears to have  commenced following the 'pilot holiday saga'.  

I tried to change my partner's seat to join me at the rear of the plane which was cheaper and I was about to pay £4 when the session timed out. When I re-entered the site to amend the seating, I  saw the seats either side of me had all of a sudden been blocked out (no other seats had been blocked out) and I was therefore left having to move myself to a seat at the front of the plane for a more expensive charge of £7. This also happened on the return leg. 

I raised this complaint with Ryanair in three attempts, but each time my complaint wasn't specifically addressed and I was sent a brief generic response  recommending the purchase of seats in advance.  I have retained the emails if required.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
I flew to Palma with my 2 daughters last year. At the earliest check in time possible I checked in and was given 3 middle seats scattered around the plane. You are then asked if you are happy with seats which I was clearly not! You  then see a plan of the plane and the available seats. From this it was clear that there were loads of seats in rows of 3, or closer together that were free. So why were we not seated together? I paid to move 1 of my daughters next to the other and I sat alone. Also when you chose a seat Ryanair they ask you not to book a middle seat!!
 So why were we given 3 unnecessarily? I know why, to make us pay to move.
I am travelling to Ryanair next month . I have not booked any seats so I am guessing the same will happen . I feel very strongly that this is a bad practice. 
I did not report this at the time because I knew the airlane wouldnt respond satisfactorily.
Thanks for reading.



Thanks for reading.

column13: We decided not to pay £16 extra to select our seats because it was too much. I have checked in very early and there were plenty seats available so I don't understand why we were separated On the day of the flight we noticed that there where empty seats on next to another and that separating us did not make any other sense as only for Ryanair to make money. Also on another flight 3 months ago we had the same incident. People were confused as everyone who chose not to pay was separated. This was not the case one year ago with Ryanair and if we checked in early enough we would not be separated. column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: None of these
column13:
I was misled into paying £120 for extra leg room seats which were together on our flight on 23rd November to Thailand from LGW, within 20 minutes of the online check in opening 24 hours prior to the flight we were placed rows apart and the seating plan was showing all passengers had checked in and no seats available together apart from the extra leg room upgrade ones at an additional charge of £60 per person. I telephoned customer services and was advised the flight was full and there were no seats together, I felt I had no option but to pay the extra with us being allocated seats some distance apart for a 12 hour flight. I had seen a Watchdog show on this previously and was sceptical of their claim that everyone had already checked in online within 20 minutes, I went onto the TUI website and attempted to book the maximum of 9 seats on the same flight and they were showing as available, so clearly the flight couldn’t have been sold out or full. This was reaffirmed when we arrived at the airport, I enquired with the representative at the bag drop and was advised that there were seats available together in economy so we could have sat together, this would have avoided the additional charge. I believe their pratices are misleading and unethical in relation to this matter.

I am still in dispute over the charge with TUI and they have so far failed to provide a satisfactory response or resolution.

column13:
We have been separated on flights into 'two's so have under 16's we had to make sure they were sat with an adult .   On occasions they have been across the aisle from each other.    These were short haul flights for skiing.
We did not report this to the airline as we managed OK.

We have flights for two adults booked later in the year with Tui to Barbados and have had to pay extra £34 per person to guarantee that we will be sat together.  As the flight is a long we feel it necessary.  On shorter routes within europe, we refuse to pay this and have sat apart.     How come airlines like Qatar, BA and schedule airlines can manage allocating seats at the time of booking without charge, never had a problem with these long haul flights.

column13: Only on a short flight from MAN-DUB so not too fussed about sitting together due to their mean seating allocation system.  Deliberately designed to make more money for the airline.    When I checked in there were plenty of rows with 2 seats available ie. window and middle but when I chose not to pay extra the airline allocated us seats.  On both flights we were at least 10 rows apart and on opposite sides of the  aircraft.  Others customers were arranging swaps on the plane to get closer to their travel companions.  It really smarts that Ryanair play these games with us just to get extra money from us.  I would rather pay an extra few quid on my ticket price and know that we would be seated together if booked early enough.   No more of these 'fees' to 'guarantee' we can sit together.  It's SO WRONG that they can get away with this.  It makes me so angry.

column13:
When we purchased the tickets no opportunity was given to reserve the seats or allocating the seat numbers. It was only discovered when we went on to the web that every seat had a extra price to pay.  More preferential seats were expensive in the same class. This was unfair.  And when we tried to do web check in all the seats had gone or we were unable to select the restricted ones. So the choice was to sit separate and right at the back of the aircraft where the seats get narrow. This way the airline is making more revenue which is not disclosed at the time of purchasing the tickets.

The Airlines should be transparent and offer the selection of seats when purchasing the tickets. Just like purchasing cinema or concert tickets with pre-allocated  seats.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: It's frustrating how Ryanair deliberately seat groups apart. In more than 10 flights over the past year, we have tested different ways of booking/checking in without paying extra and have never been seated together. Often, one of us will have a spare seat beside us, and often their system shows a plane of empty seats, and we're still assigned seats at opposite ends. On a number of occasions my flight has been delayed slightly because people take longer to get seated because people are working out how to trade seats to sit together. And on one occasion the flight was delayed significantly because a family with young children had been separated, the flight was full, and staff had to make space for them to sit together after everyone else was already seated.

column13: My wife and I have travelled with them for 20 or 30 trips, over the last 15 years, or so. When allocated seating became mandatory, we decided not to reserve a seat and take a chance. We were always say together. Then, maybe a year ago, we started to hear that those who did not pay we're being split up. The anecdotal evidence is plentiful. The Ryanair website used to say seats would be allocated at random, but whenever possible, they would be adjacent to one another. Now, they merely state that seats are selected at random. I used Ryanairs online messenger to ask that specific question about adjacent seating being the default and was told, "no, they want your money"! So while they claim their policy has not changed, their implementation of it definitely has. We paid to sit together.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: We have flown Ryanair 4 times a year for 10 years, so some 80 flights in total. We have always been seated together until last year. Since then we have been seated separately on our last 8 flights. This must be a deliberate change of policy. On the last flight, I clicked the option to change an allocated seat which reveals the seating plan and it showed me in a middle seat with one empty one next to me; and my wife also in a middle seat with an empty seat either side of her, thus creating three single seats. Any rational seating algorithm would have placed my wife next to me leaving her row empty; or me next to my wife leaving a double vacancy on my row. The fact that one can pay extra to sit together even after seats have been allocated proves it is a deliberate policy, not a lack of available seats. I have complained twice to Ryanair about this new policy but received no satisfactory reply.  Please stop them doing this.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: My partner and I were split up on a flight with RyanAir - myself in approx row 8, my partner at the back of the plane approx row 21. After the flight we realised that the lady who was sitting me, had her husband sitting next to my partner - they too had been split up, therefore, it was obvious that both couples could have been placed next to each other. There was also a large group (approx 8) that apparently had purchased tickets together but were also split across the plane. This was our experience out of London, a similar experience of being split up occurred on the return journey. We didn't want to pay extra to choose seats as it is expensive when you have to pay for both passengers, both ways. Every other airline that I have flown with in the past 12 months ex London (Easy Jet, Norwegian Air, and BA) has always put us together, or the furtherest apart would be across the isle from each other.

column3: More than 12 months ago, but within the last 2 years
column11: We did sit together
column13: During the changeover period from Virgin offering free seat reservations to charging, we were given free seat reservations as we had booked before the announcement. These were booked over the phone several months before the flight and were still showing on the seat map 48 hours before, with all 3of us sitting together. However, when completing online check in, the day before the flight, our seats had been cancelled and we were given 3 individual seats in various parts of the plane, including our 11 year old daughter sitting alone 10 rows away from her nearest parent. We were unable to change this and had to seek help at the airport. We were told that the plane seat configuration had changed last minute and as we had not paid to sit together our reservations were cancelled. We explained that we had booked when seat reservations were still free but they explained that was merely a request for specific seats and would never have been guaranteed. Thankfully,  a fantastic member of staff did some adjustments and found us seats together. Upon boarding, other families were in a similar position and the cabin crew had to ask for volunteers to move seats to allow children to sit with an adult.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
Prior to flying with Jet2, I raised my concern with the online check in process that I undertook at the earliest opportunity. I had not pre selected seats for our party as I was happy to wait until check in to do this, especially as I could see online that there was sufficient seating on both our outbound and inbound flight (including several rows of 3 seats together). However, at the point of online check in, the system auto allocated seats on separate rows (despite the availability of several groups of 3 seats in a row) and, most concerning, had put my 3 year old daughter in a seat on her own, separate from either myself or my husband. As a result, I was forced to pay the fee (nearly £60 extra in total for both flights) to self select our seats together so my daughter was not sat alone in a different part of the plane. Jet2 (on the phone) explained that the system automatically selects the first seats available from the back of the plane (and therefore does not always seat parties together). While I understand this, the system's lack of sophistication means it is unable to identify the age of its passengers and allocate seats appropriately. And this meant that I was forced to pay seat selection fees unfairly.

It took several chasing emails for Jet2 to respond, without much sympathy, but they did refund the cost of our seat allocations as a gesture of goodwill. We are now in the same position again for a holiday in June and I'm not sure what to do!
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 7.0; Moto G (5) Build/NPP25.137-15) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.137 Mobile Safari/537.36

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: As we were travelling with a young child we had to pay for a seat so one of the adults could sit next to them. We didn't pay for seating for the other 2 members of our party initially as we thought because we had booked early we would be allocated seating near each other. However, despite this we were allocated 2 seperate single seats which were at opposite ends of the plane to each other and both well away from the 2 allocated seats given to the adult & child. This has never happened before & we believe it was a deliberate act by Ryanair & was certainly not 'random' allocation. We ended up paying extra to have the seats reallocated so that we could sit together & be close to the rest of our party. Unsurprisingly when we boarded our flight there were seats which were unoccupied very close to our party which had clearly not been allocated to anyone so we could have all been sat close together without having to pay. Complete & utter con that means won't be flying Ryanair again.

column13:
I have flown with Ryanair approximately 4 times a year for over 10 years - this is the first instance that when booking a group of 2 tickets, our free seats were allocated away from each other. We always check in online as soon as it is available and our 2 free seats have always been next to each other. Funny how this time we were allocated free seats 8 rows apart when you can clearly see all the seats between us were vacant and available to be booked if we paid. 

To advise they haven’t changed their policy of ‘random’ seating allocation and confirm we were lucky to have sat together for all this time is laughable.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
TUI wanted around £80  total for two adults for both flights to prebook seats via their online checkin.  We didn’t pay as we disagreed with the charge, and we’re allocated seats at the airport which meant for the outbound fight we were sat in different rows in different areas of the cabin, and for the inbound flight we were sat in different rows. 

Before the flight, I contacted TUI several times as we wanted to check in online, but not pay for seats. First we were told there was a bug with their website - further research showed this is not the case - then we were told the seats allocated for online checkin were all taken and we needed to check in at the airport. This was a long haul flight. For two adults sitting apart was not so much of an issue, but for a family it could be a problem. We felt TUI had us to ransom over the seats. We didn’t pay the charge as the holiday was well over £2,000 so to be asked to pay a further £80 to sit together was obscene. The airline know some people would pay rather than risk being separated. It’s coldhearted and unfair and spoiled the start of our holiday. I would seriously reconsider flying with TUI again, particularly since they lied about the ‘bug’ with their website - which my research shows has been around for years. That’s not a bug, that’s a policy of making money from seating allocation.

column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
From: Douglas Capon [mailto:capondoug@gmail.com]
Sent: 10 October 2014 10:31
To: Customer Service Mailbox

Subject: Seat AllocationsI prefer not to select seats, at an extra charge, when flying with budget airlines. Instead, I check in as soon as the online facility is open but, despite prompt check-in, my wife and I were allocated seats 31f and 32f on our fight ls190 on 28/9/14; this does not particularly bother us as it is a short flight. However,the couple next to me were not related and their partners had been allocated across the aisle; a mother and her infant, next to my wife were separated from the father. After much negotiation and switching families and partners were reunited - except my wife ended up further away from me.

On ls190 on 2nd Oct, my daughter and her husband, Mr & Mrs Bryceland, were near the front of the plane and separated - the odd thing is their rows both had an empty seat! There was also much changing of seats reported by my daughter, although one passenger declined an invitation to move beside her husband, meaning my daughter and son-in-law remained unnecessarily separated.

I suspect Jet2 is deliberately using algorithms to separate passengers in order to persuade them to cough up more money in the future to book seats ahead. I can think of many reasons (from risking take-off slots to body identification) that this is not a proper practice.

Can you confirm that you deliberately split parties up or please explain why this is a common occurrence?

Our Reference: Jet2/117281
Booking Reference: 2KKGPH
Dear Mr Capon

Thank you for your email received by us on the 10th October 2014.

I was sorry to read that you were disappointed with the seats you were allocated for your recent flights with us to Palma. I understand this it is disappointing to be allocated seats separately from Mrs Capon.

I would like to explain that for customers who choose not to pre-book, seats are allocated in a sequence that starts from the back of the aircraft working forwards. The system will always miss out any seats that are already reserved or that are located within an emergency exit and it is for this reason, we cannot guarantee seats will always be allocated together. We do not want customers to be surprised by this and so we explain how the system works during the booking process.

Nevertheless, I assure you that our system is not designed to intentionally split up customers. If the next available seats in the allocation sequence are adjacent, then customers will find that they have been given seats together, without having to reserve them. However, this cannot be guaranteed and is the reason we do encourage customers to pre-book, for the extra peace of mind.

Once again, thank you for your email and for allowing me the opportunity to explain this for you. I hope that this will not deter you from flying with us again in the future.

Best regards
Sam
Samantha Kidd
Customer Service Advisor

Ryanair is the only airline I know who allows you to change your seat (if you pay) after check in. When I did this I noticed lots of free seats which evidenced they could have seated my party together. I submitted a formal complaint to the CEO and received a very abrupt response saying that we could pay to sit together but if we didn't they would "respect my wishes" to be seated rabdomly. I have retained all communication.

Dear Customer, 

Thank you for contacting Ryanair. 

Please be advised, when you checked in you were offered to select your own preferred seat. If you selected free, randomly allocated seats then you have accepted the fact you could be separated from your traveling companion. You can reallocate your seats to be sitting together, but you need to pay the associated fee to do so.
  
Yours sincerely, 

Anna

For and on Behalf of 
Ryanair DAC

column13: Booked flight tickets as couple.  On going to check in online found our seats were opposite sides of a Dreamliner - and opposite ends of the plane.  Paid extra then to sit together, but flight out were behind each other (not a problem) - return flight we were separated by an aisle and about 3 rows between each other.  The flights/holiday were booked 9 months in advance - and booked as a travelling couple - why were we sat with a whole block of seats between us and opposite ends of the plane - so we then had to pay extra and still didn't technically sit together.  Not going to bother to pay the extra the next time we fly.

column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: I bought a pair of return fllghts from Stansted to Budapest for myself and my daughter. I immediately noticed that we were automatically separated from each other. I paid the extra charge on the way out to make sure that I could sit next to my 18-year-old daughter, who is autistic. I resented this charge, as the two tickets had been bought as one purchase, but I expected the flight to be busy. I expected the return flight to be quieter, so I imagined that we might be able to move seats. The Ryanair staff were seriously active in preventing people doing this, claiming that seats were allocated to balance the plane's loading. They were very officious about this. I did not believe their claim, as the plane was full, and they hadn't weighed the individual passengers. I think the seating allocation is made to add an extra charge to parties travellling together

We then had 3 seats towards  the front of the plane with 1 at the back - in spite of a vacant seat next to a front seat.  It's so obvious that this must be arranged on purpose. column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We did not pay to choose seats as we assumed that, with an infant we would sit together. Ryanair guarantee families with a child they will sit together. Clearly this doesn’t apply for infants. 
We were seated one adult in row 11 and the other in row 23. The aircrew said they would try to move us after takeoff if there were empty seats together.  Before we took off the woman next to my husband in row 23  realised her partner was sitting next to me in row 11 so we swapped seats. Clearly both our couples had been split up on purpose.
 We moved to row 23 and found that the third seat in the row was actually empty so we could have been put in the same row anyway.  
As we didn’t want to take the chance of being apart on the return we decided to book seats together. This cost us £26 each!  When we boarded we found that again we had three seats between us as the third seat was empty. 
We felt our experience on our flight out was designed to ‘encourage’ us to pay in future.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
Ryan Air staff informed us that seats were "randomly allocated"  Cabin staff seating us claimed this was to "ensure aircraft safety by balancing the weight within the cabin".   (As a former BOAC Chief Steward myself I believed this to be untrue and nonsense). 

The 'random allocation' ensured that all members of the party were separated and spaced apart in a manner that appeared to defy randomness. We managed to do some exchanges after take-off to ensure that at least parents and children were close together.  As we only had a short flight to France it was not too much of a problem for us. However, we were very annoyed that the seating was deliberately  arranged to separate members of our group and patently a sanction for not paying  their sitting together surcharges  avoid their version of 'random  allocation'.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13: Two of our party wanted to sit together as one of them had recently broken her wrist and the other was a nervous flyer so they paid extra.  The rest of us weren't bothered so didn't pay extra and were dotted around the plane.  That's fine, except that Ryanair appear to have changed their policy so that if you don't pay extra, then they deliberately seat you far apart - this has happened to me on more than one occasion.  This didn't use to be Ryanair's policy (I've not paid any extra and have ended up sitting next to my partner/friend on more than one occasion)  and it didn't happen on our journey home when, due to ATC problems, our flight was cancelled and we took two flights with Vuelling and one with  Easyjet - we all sat together, or very close together, without paying any extra.  I'm happy with random seating and taking pot luck, what I don't like is the apparent policy of deliberately being seated far apart from my travelling companions.  I think it's potentially dangerous as well - in the event of an emergency or sudden illness, family and friends would naturally want to be near each other so would be moving around the plane trying to swap seats.

Our seats were on the return were not together and I called Thomson to say that the children would be upset if we don't sit together. I was told that four seats were not available together (even if we'd paid) but assured that the flight attendants would sort it out on the flight as we would have to be in a situation to help the children in an emergency.

The return flight was full and it was very difficult for the flight attendants to move our family so we were sitting close to each other. I also caused anger among other passengers who had paid for their seats and didn't want to move.

Since then, we have had to pay for seat selections which adds a few hundred pounds to our holiday cost.

The exception (so far) is British Airways which always seems to allocate our seats together about 5 days before the flight.

column3: More than 12 months ago, but within the last 2 years
column11: None of these
column13:
We flew with Ryanair from Bristol airport to Malaga airport on the 20th June 2017 flight numbers FR8121 and FR8122.

I didn't pay to 'choose' my seat as I believe that the addition of this charge should be illegal. The consistent pay as you go nature of airline travel needs to stop and single ticket prices need to return that include meals/ drinks/seats and luggage. Airlines can then be profitable again and we stop feeling like they are scamming us.

I booked our flight to Spain to see my partners parents but waited until the required '24 -48 hours' before flying check-in time that Ryanair demands. This is when they give you your boarding pass that you have to print (or use their app) and allocate your seat. 
While I was going through the motions online and clicked the random allocate button, I spotted that we were not put together. This was very odd because there were at least 15 options that they could have sat us together. Also, we were both put into the middle of a 3 row of seats, one of us towards the front and one of us towards the back. This then means that 6 seats have been disrupted so people cannot sit together. Interestingly Ryanair claim this is totally random but surely it's in their interests to keep seats free in case more people want to pay to sit together not block them? 
While I was online looking at this and feeling scammed, someone else must have been online and checked in as my seat disappeared and there was an error. I was told I needed to ring up to get my booking confirmed. 
Now, this is when it got interesting while speaking to Ryanair, the person confirmed that someone else was allocated the seat I had. I told them, my partners, seat number and explained how she had both seats either side of her free and it would be nice to sit together as she is pregnant and scared of flying.
 I was told they would 'speak to someone'
When they came back the answer was 'sorry it's totally random would you like to pay' 
I thought sod it ill pay for 1. the buggers.
I was then told 'no I have to pay for both' even though my partner's seat had already been allocated.
This annoyed me a bit so I said nope just allocate my seat. Surely this is illegal? apparently not....
Surprise surprise my seat was deliberately not anywhere near my partner and in the middle of yet another row of 3 with empty seats either side of me.

Now interestingly on the plane chaos ensued because people were running up and down the plane to talk to their partners while the poor staff were trying to get people in their seats so we didn't miss our takeoff window. They should have expected this if they were deliberately sitting people apart.

Also to rub salt in the wound, both the seats either side of my partner were empty throughout the flight so I could have been allocated one of them.

Needless to say, I felt scammed, this was a deliberate attempt by a shameless airline that tries different scams all the time to scrape extra money out of people and cause unnecessary stress when you're going on holiday. I am pleased you are looking into this and feel free to contact me to discuss this further. 

Later in the year, we flew with Monarch (The day before they went bust) and the random allocation sat us together as it should if there is space to do so. On a side note, I would like to thank you for your handling of that time as we felt well looked after by the CAA. 

Warm regards 

Keith - Never flying with Ryanair again I would rather pay more for my flight at a different airport than fly with them again, that's how scammed I felt.

We are a family group of adults, all with the same surname. Flying return with Jet2 from Edinburgh (EDI) to Palma (PMI). Outward flight, 2 pax sitting in rear row, window and middle seat and 1 pax sitting last but one row at window. Plane was full, but noticed a scramble after take off with people attempting to sit with friends/relatives. Thought this was a one off. However:
On return, 2 pax in mid plane row middle and aisle seat. 1 pax (me) one row behind on aisle seat. Pax opposite me (across the aisle) stated her husband was in window seat next to my two family members and 'do you want to swap so I can sit across the aisle from him'. 
It was then that I strongly suspected that Jet2 were using an algorithm to prevent pax sitting together if they don't pay for this. Another scramble ensued after take off. I now refuse to fly Jet2.

column13:
We checked In online very soon after the online check in window opened. Our "randomly" allocated seats were about 10 rows apart, both in middle seats. When we got on the plane, it was obvious that nobody who hadn't paid was seated together.
As it happened, there were spare seats so my wife and I just moved.
The same happened on the return flight. The flights were Stansted to Pisa return 19th to 22nd June 2017.
We spoke to people on the flights and it was clear that most people were allocated middle seats several rows apart, this then severely reduces the amount of available seats that are together for people that check in later.
I complained to Ryanair who sent me a standard response about how their policy had not changed. This is simply a lie. I travelled with Ryanair twice, in December 2015 and Feb 2016 and on both occasions, our party of 4 was seated together with no payment.

column13:
We travelled with my elderly mother who has a medical issue which means she needs to get up and move about on a regular basis. We booked the seats to ensure we were able to sit across the aisle and be able to quickly support her when she needed it.
If seats can be pre-booked, why can't seats be allocated at the time of booking the flight / holiday (like booking seats in a theatre) which would reduce the need for further payments to be made? Additionally, as a Health & Safety professional, I am amazed that any Airline would be happy separating parents from children - not good if there was severe turbulence or an incident.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13: We fly with Ryanair 3-4 times a year therefore we try to play the travel game their way to suit us.  As seniors we take only "wheelies" plus one and try to be last on so they take our wheelies in the hold gratis (first 92 get wheelies on). Since the latest seat debacle we have yet to circumnavigate this one without paying for at least one seat.  Ref para7 above, we are given the option to select a seat but only at a cost which depends on where the allocated seat is located. Also, seat allocation occurs 24 hours before flight which severely impacts on seat choice if you decide to move and purchase. Since the latest carry on debacle we apply the wheelie manoeuvre  described above so that we get our second piece of luggage on board at no extra cost.  We have never reported any concerns to the airline, we just play the game !
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.140 Safari/537.36

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We considered paying to sit together but thought the fee (minimum £9 each) too expensive.  On checking the seating plan where we could have selected seats, it was obvious that many pairs of seats remained unallocated at the time of booking and check in.  We were allocated far apart 'random' seats (check in was 'open' at time of booking as we were within 60 days of the flight).

We have a holiday home and fly five or six return flights a year.  We usually use both Ryanair and Easyjet regularly and don't pay for allocated seats.  Our recent experience is that Easyjet invariably allocate us seats together, without extra payment, but Ryanair ALWAYS deliberately allocate seats many rows apart, despite many pairs of seats actually being available because they had not been reserved by others making payment to do so.

Thank you for investigating this issue.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.140 Safari/537.36

In spite of Ryamsor saying check hand bags in to the hold avoid delays bringing then on board I have found recently the greatest waste of time has been in trying to reorganize seating before take off so parties especially families with children can be seated together. I fly to Spain frequently with Ryanair and have shared many tales of parties split up but lots of empty seats around them.

When we were airborne the man also in the row with me asked if it was ok to ask his wife to move and sit with him - or if I wanted to ask my partner . He went to fetch his wife - who was 'randomly'!! sitting next to my partner .

So when the seats were allocated I could have been placed with my partner and the man could have been placed with his wife . This was obviously deliberately separating couples/ groups unless they pay extra.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did sit together
column13: We were able to book our preffered seats for approx £8 per person per flight sector. For standard seats on a shorthaul flight, this is probably the most i would wish to pay to have our preference on where to on the aircraft and to guarantee seats together. I feel it is a fair system and everyone else who doesnt wish to pay are given seats on a first come first served basis - again which i feel is very fair. What i would find unfair is a system that purposely splits people up online or where the airport is always left with little choice to seat people there. I also feel a maximum charge for a standard seat preference for UK/EU airlines should perhaps be considered. Any more than £10pp per sector is excessive.

column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered about doing so (e.g. it was a short flight, we didn’t mind sitting apart etc)
column13: The itinerary was ATH-CDG-SXM. First leg on a A321, 2nd leg on an A340. It was a group ticket for a total of 21 people. 4 didn't mind where their seat would be so the airline gave them isle seats on the A321 and between the isles on the A340 (If memory serves me, seating configuration was 2-5-2 abreast). The rest of us turned up at the initial check-in desk at ATH with a request for window seats on both legs. The airline indeed and to everyone's surprise granted our request. When we reached CDG the transit clerk called for us thinking there has been a mistake with our seat allocation (a group ticket scattered around the cabin) and to our horror offered to put us all together. We declined and again our request was granted. A group ticket seated in tandem. Well done Air France!

Easyjet will keep group bookings together, yet ryanair split up 3 seperate 2-person bookings into 3 individual seats on different rows?  Slime.

column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
BA allocated separate seats and by the time check-in was open there were no 2 seats together available. We hadn't paid extra for the seats as we had booked under the Companion voucher scheme and assumed that we'd be treated as a group.
We complained to BA and were given the 'operational / safety issues' response which was nonsense as I swapped seats with a single traveller on the outbound flight to NY and the desk agent in NY made swaps at boarding on the return flight to have us sit together.
I complained through BA's complaints system. They responded once and closed the file. I e-mailed for clarification and asked to be contacted by e-mail - they telephoned. I restated my complaint - they honed again. Then closed the case. I e-mailed 3 times to the Chief Exec and got the same (now identified as a lie) response about operational issues. I asked for a refund of my voucher and they refused. Their customer service is shocking.

column13: We were a group of 4 persons, 3 with the same surname, flying 10.5 hours to Mexico. The plane was a 3x3x3 configuration. 3 of us were sat 1 in front of the other with a 2 row gap to the next person on the outbound flight, not great but not good. On the return flight we were scattered around the cabin like leaves. Numerous people were complaining about seating allocation. Even the most basic of software seating programmes or a trained chimpanzee, after taking out the paid for allocated seating could have done a better job of seating this plane to most persons satisfaction and the crew spent the first 15/20mins after loading of trying to resolve issues, most of which they did. I believe this was an intentional ploy by TUI to split groups so that next time they flew they paid for allocated seating. All they achieved is that I would look for a different airline before I had to fly with them again.

column13: We didn't realise until we did online check in that we wouldn't be sat together.  On boarding plane it became apparent that people were deliberately sat apart from who they were travelling with.  There was empty seats next to people who were not travelling alone but weren't sat with their travel companion either.  We paid to sit together on return journey when checking in online.  We were disgusted with Ryanair for deliberately sitting us apart and us having to pay to sit together with this flight and a flight we also had pre booked in the future as their seating algorithm changed after we had made bookings so felt we shouldn't have been charged. We emailed Ryanair a complaint but got no resolution other than the initial email acknowledging our email of complaint. It put us off booking our next few flights with them, we switched to easyjet their competitor in protest.

column13:
I think this was the first time we had flown Ryanair since this charge was introduced. Previously on Easyjet we had been seated together despite not having paid extra, so we hoped it wouldn't be necessary and that we might be seated together anyway.
On the outward flight, we checked in as soon as we were allowed to without paying extra, and it seemed we were definitely seated as far apart and in as undesirable seats as possible as my husband was in about row 15 and I was in 37 or something, and we both had middle seats, even though the majority of seats were still unallocated.
On the way back we decided to leave check-in as late as possible as the seating couldn't be worse. In fact it was quite a lot better. I had an aisle seat in the exit row with plenty of leg room, and my husband had an aisle seat too, though at the back. I suspect I only got this seat because all the bad seats had gone by the time we checked in.

We were a party of 3 couples - on the outward flight 1 couple were allocated seats together, 1 couple were allocated seats 1 row apart and the 3rd couple only one person was allocated a seat! The check in clerk had to search for a seat and managed to find one in the same row. 
On the return flight one couple were allocated seats in the same row, and the two other couples were sat several rows apart. When we complained at Turin the clerk said he couldn’t rearrange and to ask on the plane. This we did and were told that they would see what they could do once everyone was onboard, then didn’t hear anything else! Two of us swapped seats to be in rows nearer to our partners but only after gett8ng together after the flight did we discover that there were empty seats together at the rear of the plane so we are not sure why the seating was so random.

column11: We did sit together
column13:
For the last 5 years or so, I have flown on holiday with my husband and/ or family.
I do not enjoy flying and this makes me anxious throughout the flight. Due to this, I feel forced to pre book our seats to ensure I am sat next to my husband, which I resent doing as I think the cost of the flight, usually a very large amount, should be sufficient to allow this. The fear of being separated is compounded on long haul flights, forced to pay for seats to avoid the worry rather than enjoying the excitement of looking forward to the holiday. Years ago, when no-one pre booked seats, there did not appear to be this issue over seating, but this has now become an additional money earner for the airlines - by some passengers booking seats has forced others to have to do the same - or risk being separated.

column13: Booked 3 tickets for my wife, myself and a friend on Ryanair from East Midlands to Berlin on a for day trip. Flight number FR1638 on the 15th January 2018 and FR1639 19th January 2018. When checking in we were told it would be random seating unless we paid extra to sit together. On checking in I was placed in seat 20b, my wife was in seat 9e and our friend in 8e. On looking at the seating plan i could have purchased the two seats next to my wife but it was going to cost £9 per seat a total of £36 for the round trip. On the way back from Berlin I was placed in seat 14e my wife and friend were sat in seats 12e and 12f. There seemed to be lots of people swapping seats to sit with their friend, partners or even their own children. I have flown with Ryanair for some years, and before their so called random seating if you booked two tickets you would be allocated two seats together. I feel they are splitting people up on purpose to try and force them to pay to sit together.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
Since Ryanair introduced its ‘random’ seat allocation.  We have travelled in various groups on approximately 6 return flights. We have never been sat together, on any of them.  On one flight from Stanstead to Madrid when there were 6 of us, who had booked at the same time; we were all given middle seats a various positions on the plane.
Another flight from Stanstead to Castellon, my husband and I were separated, even though I had an entire row of seats to myself and there was a spare seat next to him as well.
My husband is a retired fire officer and he wrote to Ryanair, asking them to consider the situation, that if there was an’incident’ on one of their flights, with so many people being split up from their loved ones, there could be absolute chaos. It is human nature, that people would desperately try to find their loved ones, rather than head for the nearest emergency exit.  Ryanair’s response was,  that if we were unhappy about the seating, we like every other passenger, had the opportunity to pay to sit together. 
Prior to May 2017 we had never experienced this problem and were always seated together as a group.

column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
we did not pay for sitting next to each other and accepted that we would be seperated. When we boarded a large majority of people appeared to have done the same however some had paid to sit together.
  Once we had taken off a passenger asked teh cabin crew if they could move further down the plane to sit with their partner.  cabin crew agreed and the passenger moved.  The lady who moved, her seat was then vacant and another passenger then moved into that seat to be with her partner.  this had a snowball effect any many people including myself moved.  The only people not happy were the ones that has paid to sit together.
  This was somewhat disruptive for a short period of time and not sure on the safety issue of anyone knowing who was sitting where.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
sitting apart was more of an inconvience. The flight was almost full.  I felt it caused a safety issue.  Once seat belt sign was off people were getting up and going to  where other people they were traveling with were sitting and standing chatting to them.  Cabin crew needing to get pass with their trollys  were struggling .
 I had a rather large   gentleman standing in the isle leaning so close, I was sitting in the isle seat, he was standing   talking to the lady who was next to me in the middle seat.
 I got so fed up with them having a conversation across me I suggested in the end we changed seats. Other people were calling several rows back and forward to each other.
On a safe issue it must be better for people to be able to sit next to their traveling companion than standing in the isle talking to them. 
 Had this been a later timed flight and trying to get some sleep this would have been unbearable.

column13:
I am unwilling to pay extra to sit together, and assume that I will be able to choose seats when online checkin opens.  For outward flight (In Aug 2017 with Tui) it had automatically allocated us seats in 3 separate rows despite there being plenty of seats together (so appears to be a punishment), and to alter them we still had to pay (money making endeavour).  For return flight happily it had allocated seats together.

Re Emirates I am exceedingly disappointed they have introduced this charge as I was accustomed to going online and choosing my seat for free the minute I booked my tickets - I do not think it is appropriate to have this charge for long haul fights.

When there are available seats together at point online checkin opens I believe there should be an obligation on the airline to seat you together.

To ensure we could have all the family sitting together we therefore had to pay more than £200 to book our seats in advance.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
My daughter (14 years) and I were flying from Belfast to Malaga during the school holidays at the end of October 2017.  When online booking opened I immediately checked in expecting as it was so early to be seated beside my daughter even though I knew the seat would be picked randomly.  I am a frequent flyer with Ryanair so checking in early always worked for me.  To my horror my daughter was seated in row 15 and I was seated in row 25.  Every row beside me was vacant and quite a few around my daughter were vacant too.  I had to pay I think £12.99 to sit beside my daughter.

We flew again with Ryanair circa 16th December 2017.  On this occasion I waited to the last minute to check online.  We got together much closer this time with Holly seated in the middle seat of row 3 and I was seated in the middle seat of row 5.  All the seats around us were vacant and this time I jumped in beside my daughter just prior to takeoff when the doors were closed.

I have pictures of the seating arrangements on both occasions if required.

column13:
Our 3 seats were split across 3 different rows, all middle seats.  We were not comfortable allowing our (just) 13yr old daughter sitting between 2 strangers, especially when neither me or my husband were close enough to be able to watch her.
We ended up paying for allocated seats at nearly £15 each way on our return flight.
There was a great deal of choice for us to choose our seats when we proceeded to do so and so did not agree with the airlines explanation that seats were chosen at random as we've flown a number of times previously and never had this issue (only since they changed their seating policy).
It would also not allow us to book just 2 of the seats together (thus reducing the cost) so we were forced to pay for all 3 seats in order to protect our daughters safety.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
March 2017 6 adults flew Ryanair. ....all sat together across the plane. July 2017 same journey with Ryanair 2 adults - one sat at front of plane and one at rear although plane not full and we both had empty seats nearby. I did raise issue with stewardess as boarding passes for both of us on my phone and we boarded at opposite ends of the plane. She was not interested , very abrupt
and said that was our problem and we both needed our passes to board.  Had pre empted this problem and my travelling companion had photographed his pass. Did raise this issue when giving feedback but no response from Ryanair. 
My son lives in Germany and often uses this Ryanair flight.  Since middle of 2017 always split up from his girlfriend.  Frustration is Ryanair only provider on this route so unable to protest at this treatment by using a different airline.

Also travel a couple of times each year with Tui.  Never any problem with seating arrangements always sat together. 

Don't mind been separated if it's a full flight but splitting bookings up just to make customers pay extra to sit together seems to be the policy with some airlines.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 5.1.1; SAMSUNG SM-T280 Build/LMY47V) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) SamsungBrowser/6.2 Chrome/56.0.2924.87 Safari/537.36

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: I personally don’t understand why Ryanair can not sit groups and couples together - as they used to. There are so many add-ons to a booking that paying extra to guarantee seats together on both outbound and inbound flights that it can add a significant amount to the overall cost. What’s also important to remember is that they advertise seats at the lowest cost - ie the rows right at the back of the plane. These sell out first leaving no option but to be faced with upwards of £20 to reserve a middle of the plane seat. If easy jet, Norwegian and many other low cost airlines can operate with an alternative model how can Ryanair justify this? They know that people will pay extra to sit together but it’s just morally wrong. A booking with the same ref no should guarantee seats together.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 11_2_5 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/604.5.6 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.0 Mobile/15D60 Safari/604.1

We were not offered the chance to change or pay to sit together but when we got to the airport in Dubai and asked about sitting together we were given two seats for free together in extra legroom seating.  

We have noticed that on checking in online for flights we are increasingly being seated apart and encouraged to pay extra to sit together.   Yet this experience shows that it was not necessary to pay extra in advance.

We booked four tickets NCL to New York with Jet2 at the beginning of December. Flights for the four of us were £1800, but Jet2 wanted an extra £30 per person per flight to book a seat which we decided was too expensive and resulted in us all being separated

Fortunately this had happened to many on the plane so were able so swap with other passengers so we could sit together 

There was lots of other groups of the plane, all separated which meant many people were standing in the aisles to talk to people they knew. It made it an uncomfortable flight because you could relax and it was difficult for the crew to do trolley service as people were standing in the aisles 
An extra £240 to be able to sit together when you’ve already paid nearly £2000 is extortionate

column13:
Outbound from Mallorca seats were automatically allocated during online check in and were all together without us having to pay to select to sit together.
On the inbound flight when we checked in online we were all seated in different rows despite travelling with a one year old and a three year old.  We didn't see why we should pay to be seated - the two non-parent adults didn't mind where they sat and we couldn't believe that the airline would make such young children sit apart from the mother. Fortunately when we checked our bags in and explained the situation to the EasyJet lady on the check in desk she was able to arrange for us to sit together after making a phone call. She sat all of us together even though we explained that we only needed the children to be with the mother. So, stressful to start with but we were very pleased with how the situation was rectified.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/58.0.3029.110 Safari/537.36 Edge/16.16299

column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: We booked with BA but the flight/airline was AA. Outbound London HR to Miami was fine & we were allocated seats together during online check in without paying to do so. During online check in for the return flight Miami to London HR we were automatically sat apart in different rows and to select seats together we had to pay an additional cost. There were plenty of seats available for the flight, all window and aisle seats were a charge to sit in. We selected seats that were apart to complete the online check in process without additional cost. On arrival at the airport we asked about changing the seats so that we could sit together and were told that we would have to pay to allocate our seats together. We refused to pay and were sat separately for take off. Following take off the seat beside me was still unoccupied so my wife moved seat to sit beside me for the flight.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: Every time we fly with Ryanair, we make one booking for the 3 of us in the family. When it comes to checking in, we select random allocation as I do not wish to pay extra to choose seats. I always make sure I check in very close to the time when online check in opens. The computer always allocates us random middle seats for the 3 of us spread out throughout the cabin so its not even close to each other. Then a window pops up, saying: you are not seating together, would you like to sit together? Then pay xx amount now to choose your seats. This has happened now 3 times flying with this airline. Once when i paid for seats as we got separated again, I could clearly see the plane was empty as pretty much every seat was available to choose for a fee, but we were completely separated. After I contacted the airline the reply I received was I should pay to make sure we sit together and avoid this in the future. It is clear to me that is a complete rip off to the passengers and really hope something is done about this.

column13:
We were split up across the plane to and from Italy, as were another family we spoke to who checked in a couple of days before us and were in the same situation again on the return flight. In fact, I was sat next to the Mother from the other group, my husband next to the son, my Father next to their daughter and my Mother next to the Father from the other group. This family checked in a clear 2 days earlier than us. There was absolutely no reason at that time to separate that family. All of them could've sat together and so could we.

I've flown on Ryanair at least 2-3 times per year since 2007, never paid for seats together and ALWAYS been allocated seats together. Until July last year and every subsequent flight since, my group has been separated.

There has quite clearly been a deliberate policy change with a view to making extra money off passengers.

column13:
On this flight we had been allocated a seat for the 8 year old with 1 adult. We were unable to pay for seats with the child as all the centre section of the plane is reserved for children and 1 adult from their party resulting in all families being sat separately. This also happened on a day trip to Lapland. There was no facility to check in on line. Yet a family who were the very first to check in were split up. Impossible really, unless it’s intentionally set up to do that. This was Thomas cook. The result of this was a hour and 5 minutes delay in departure. As we only had about 8 hours in Lapland this impacted the experience greatly. 40 minutes in Santa Claus village! £954 for my 8 year old grandaughter anf me for a day trip!
We will be flying to Orlando in March and are considering paying £30 per seat for 5 adults an 8 year old and a baby adding £420 to our booking. We didn’t know about this cost until we tried to check in! Also, if it’s compulsory for the 8 year old to sit with an adult why do I have to pay to allocate her a seat? 
Budapest in September, same thing, 3 sat separately. Disgusting!

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
I don't believe in paying for a seat, simply because airlines ask silly money for them, but that said, it appears only recently have they been proactive about deliberately splitting people up, even in a party of 2. We travelled to Tenerife, and the number of people on the flight we spoke to who had been split up was very apparent. For the first hour or so, it was like musical chairs with people talking to others and swapping seats as a result. Staff were ok about this, however I expect this would affect their on board sales as the trolley couldn't progress through the plane very well. Bad news for the staff, who are normally on commission based sales, but "one back at ya" to Ryanair for this and hopefully it affect their sales figures on board.
If they are going to continue to randomly split parties, then they may as well scrap it altogether and allow people to board like a bus!
After all, they can't leave you behind....

I contacted Thomas Cook when we got home to complain that I had paid for allocated seats that I did not get. They refunded £40.  On the flight there were people who had not paid for  allocated seats, they had children with thethem but checked in after most other people so we're given seats that were not all together. They made a fuss when they got on the plane and this resulted in people that had paid to choose their seats being forced to move to accommodate them as the captain refused to take off until the children were sat with the parents.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13: I heard Ryanair had started separating groups by allocating middle seats all over the plane to encourage them to pay to sit together. So as soon as I could check in I looked at what was still available on the seating plan, pretending that I wanted to buy a seat. It was noticeable that a lot of middle seats had gone, and there were only a few people sitting together (presumably those who had paid). I over the next day or two I kept checking the seating plan, and eventually all the middle seats had gone (except extra legroom middle seats at £16 extra, and priority middle seats at the front of the plane at £9 extra). I then checked in because at least we would then be given a window or aisle seat (but no chance of sitting next to my husband, even if I wanted to pay, as all the middle seats had gone!). But Ryanair preferred to allocate us, free of charge, an extra legroom middle seat and a priority middle seat at opposite ends of the plane rather than, for example, two aisle seats near each other. Once on the plane, passengers were swapping seats so that they could sit next to others in their party, which caused some chaos. Ryanair’s plan to make people pay for seats has totally backfired, as everyone that I know who used to fly with Ryanair has now decided to fly with EasyJet instead!
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/63.0.3239.132 Safari/537.36

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: Ryanair have recently changed their hand luggage policy and you are now only able to take one piece of cabin luggage onto the plane unless you pay approximately £5 extra for Priority Boarding then you are allowed two pieces, each of a certain size. We paid the additional price for Priority Boarding so that we could both have two pieces of hand luggage. Ryanair also only allow you to check in online four days before your flight unless you are prepared to pay to have an allocated seat which we were not prepared to do. On checking in we were given the option of choosing our seats but chose not to as we didn't want to pay the extra. Subsequently, we were given seats several rows apart. This is despite the fact that there were empty seats on the flight and one row of seats had only one occupant near to where my Husband sat. It is obvious that this is a ploy by Ryanair to get more money out of travellers knowing that they would like to sit together. Despite extensive air travel, we have chosen not to fly with Ryanair because of their sharp practices but this was the only flight available at a suitable time.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13: The new system with Ryanair can only be described as a new way to increase their take but without putting it onto advertised prices. I see this as disingenuous. We booked on the same booking and whilst I understand that they allegedly allocate seats randomly it is not beyond the wit of thier IT team to programme their system to allocate randomly in the groups the bookings were made. As I see it they deliberately separate couples in the hope that they will pay the surcharge to the advertised price next trip. We are not going to pay but the policy of raising large percentages of their income in "extras" is not a transparent or clear way to trade and regulators, whether CAA or trading and advertising standards should clamp down on this.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:58.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/58.0

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
My son is a an anxious flier and sitting in a particular area on the aircraft makes the flight much easier for him.
In order to reduce stress, one  member of the family sits next to him in his chosen area.
We pay for these two seats at the time of booking to ensure this arrangement.
The rest of the party chooses payment- free seats either at check-in 24 hours prior to travelling or at the airport.
We prefer to choose seats close to the pre-paid ones but availability does not always allow this.
I cannot understand how airlines can charge extra for seats when the "seat" has already been paid for on the flight booking. 
We have recently had to pay £68 per seat on an American Airlines flight on top of the flight booking to reduce his  stress. Shocking.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did not sit together because we didn’t know until we boarded that our seats were apart
column13:
At check in we were advised we could not sit together, for the 12 hours flight.
 
We were informed the flight was full.  He said there is a new policy and that we would need to pay more to sit together.  Our flight out to Santiago did not have the same problem and we were merely sat together.
 
We were advised that the only way to sit together back to Heathrow was to upgrade to Business class.
 
Making clear that we were not happy the check in person who was helpful and understanding said he would try to accommodate us by moving passengers around.  This he could only do at the gate.  So we were in suspense, allocated with middle seats between passengers, many rows apart, and we were not at all happy, despite checking in over 3 hours in advance.
 
He also called his supervisor who confirmed the upgrade option.  Then saying he would see what he could do.
 
At the gate we, along with a number of other passengers were called to the desk to be given new boarding passes allowing us to sit together.
 
There appears to be a clear policy to have passengers to pay for seats to sit together, this can only be to make more money, but BA are not concerned about passengers and don’t realise they are better off just charging the variance across the whole flight to keep passengers happy.  If a seat booking IS £30 per passenger then I’m sure £60 for a couple included at the outset is preferable to becoming an unhappy passer and the repute of the airline and CAA isa at stake, for not policing, what is in effect exploitation and forcing of upgrades.
 
I have not bothered writing to BA as the usual unsatisfactory answer would be received. 
 
The irony is, we were seated in row 16 and my seat was faulty, it was not locked into the upright position and rocked back and forward also to the annoyance of the passenger in the row behind.  Had I paid extra for this seat (emergency row with no seats infront additional leg room etc) then I would not have been happy either.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_11_6) AppleWebKit/604.5.6 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.0.3 Safari/604.5.6

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
Last flight with Ryanair (an almost full flight with approximately 4 empty seats): Woman nearby moved forward one row to empty seat next to her partner then was told off by steward who said seats are allocated for H&S to balance the aeroplane. My partner and I were both sitting next to another couple who had been purposefully split up so we just switched seats with them to sit together. We didn't ask due to previous experience, detailed below.

Previous Ryanair flight (about a third full): Asked steward if I could move to empty seat next to my partner and was told couldn't switch seats unless I wanted to pay for a different seat, so we sat separately for flight. Almost everyone else on plane had all been split up, they just got up and moved to empty seats without asking.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
It was quite clear that the manner in which the random allocation selected seats was a clear attempt to “punish” passengers who refuse to pay the additional charge.  It was also apparent that although you can go back into their site and change your seat after allocation, the pricing is higher to select a seat during this process.  I only managed to find 1 Seat priced at £4 during this process.

I booked 13 people on the flight over 4 reference numbers but all booked by me via my Ryanair Account.  Below I have listed the names and the seats they were allocated as part of the random process:

Ref beginning P2

                            Out           Return
D Cullen           8B             16B
L Reid.              19E.           17B.    (My partner)
B Hope.            9C.             32B
H Hope.            32C.          1B.      (Clearly husband and wife)
G Crawford.     8D.             31B
S Crawford.     23D.           05E.  (clearly husband and wife)
K Garden.        29B.           23E
C Smith.          20D.           23F. (I had to pay £20 to Seat this couple together both ways as C Smith is a nervous flyer)

Ref beginning A3

T Rourke.         6F.             19D
J Tasker.           19A.          21D

Ref Beginning P2

A McLuckie.    7E.            8E
J MCLuckie.    6B.           22E

Ref Beginning R4

W McIntyre.      10A.       7B

Once I became aware of the issue, I then contacted their customer service.  It is 13p per minute to phone, so I went on to their online chat.  It took 2 hours and 3 attempts to get no where other than go back and pay more.  And I got the distinct impression that the CS staff just cut you off when the conversations gets difficult.

column13: I was studying at UK (Wye Collage, Univ. of London) and then working for more than 10 years at University of Warwick. Part of my family still lives at UK. That is why I am traveling to UK (to collect and then return my daughter - she is 12 now) quite often mainly using the Ryanair. During booking of my flits when I asked for allocating random seats for me and my daughter, it has never happened to me, that we would not be seated next to each other. Situation has totally changed about 1-2 years ago – since then it has never happened to me that we would be allocated seats next to each other – EVERYTIME we were seated at least 10 rows apart. It is not coincidence, it is rule. It is computer programme. I would not mind paying few more pounds, but I hate such hidden expenses, or simply this swindle policy of the so-called low-cost airlines.
