column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
I checked us in online 4 days in advance (the max. allowed without paying extra).   My sister was booked as a WCHR needing wheelchair assistance.  We were numbers 44 and 45 to check in on a 189 seater plane so plenty of seats together.  We were allocated 11E and 20B. A message immediately appeared on screen to say we were seated apart and in middle seats but we could pay to sit together.  Although I did not pay to change seats on principle I clicked on ‘yes please’ in order to see the seat plan.  Both seats on either side of myself and my sister were free, indicating that the Ryanair system is set up to purposely separate people checking in together on the same reservation into separate middle seats.  I complained to the staff at the gate and onboard as my sister needed assistance but they just shrugged.
The same happened on the return flight.  We were allocated 22B and 33B.  Again when consulting the seating plan there were empty seats together either side of both of us.  Again the staff were indifferent.

column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13: Despite checking in very late we were allocated seat numbers 10 rows apart. However both of us were seated next to empty seats.  There were several other empty seats, and people not sitting together who wanted to be. Someone came and sat next to me to sit next to the third occupant of the row, and there was generally about 10 minutes of random moving about of perhaps 20 passengers, many of whom were using whatsapp to say "There's a seat next to me!" People were removing their overhead luggage, someimtes two people were heading to the same empty middle seat. It was pretty chaotic, but also quite surprising how people managed to find an organic way to move around. This was on a 50 minute flight. I was happy to sit apart from my partner to avoid the mayhem.

column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We booked with Virgin but the flight/airline was Delta. Outbound flight Manchester to New York JFK was fine & we were allocated seats together during online check in without paying to do so. During online check in for the return flight NY JFK to Manchester we were automatically sat apart in different rows and to select seats together we had to pay an additional cost. We did not complete online check in instead opting to wait until the airport as we thought that there must be a problem which they could sort for us at the airport. 

On arrival at the airport we did the check in process at a computer, when it again automatically sat us separately we called a staff member over. The staff member said there was no problem and that we had to pay to select our seats to sit together despite there being plenty of available seats. When we said that we would not pay the staff member at check in suggested that we should get to the boarding gate early to ask at the desk at the boarding gate if they could reallocate our seats. Therefore we finished the check in process selecting seats that were apart. 

We were some of the first people to arrive at the boarding gate, when a staff member arrived at the desk at the boarding gate we approached her and explained the situation asking if we could be allocated new seats. Thankfully she was very helpful and stated that she had already noticed that our group was sat apart and was happy to allocate us with new seats sat together. She issued us with new boarding cards and thankfully we were able to sit together for the flight. 

During the flight it was obvious that we were not the only group that had been allocated separate seats from our travelling group during check in but these groups hadn't had their situation resolved as ours had been. Once we had boarded the plane we were approached by many other passengers asking if we were together/if we would swap seats as their group had been split up. Also during the flight many people were getting up from their own seat to walk down to where their significant other was sat to stand beside their seat to be with them during the flight.

column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
Hello,
 
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42931091
 
In response to the BBC article (see link above) on Airline Operators abuse of their seating policy. I would like to confirm that Ryan Air is a consistent abuser of such acts, based on my personal experience in using this operator. I usually travel with my husband as a party of 2 and so far they have split us on both legs of the flights that we have been on with this operator.
 
 I would ask the CAA to review the algorithms used and seating policies of airliners to ensure that they are not maliciously trying to split parties in order to force travellers to pay a charge to sit next to each other. I am happy if airline operators are not able to provide a guarantee of seating passengers together while offering a service to pay for such a guarantee. However if airline operators are maliciously using algorithms to split parties up then this is an abuse on consumer protection laws and rights. In addition there should be severe fines for breaches to deter operators from carrying out such practices in the future.
 
From my experience with Easy Jet & Jet2, I have not had this issue. 
 
Regards,
Tanzina

column13:
Hello,

If my recent experience is anything to go by, it is most definitely the policy of some airlines, e.g. Ryanair, to deliberately split up groups when 'randomly' allocating seats. 

Back in May 2017 I checked in my parents and their friends for a Ryanair East Midlands-Dublin flight. My parents and their friends did not want to book an allocated seat as they weren't fussed about their location on the plane. However, they did mistakenly assume that they would be seated together. As you will see below by the seats allocated, this couldn't be further from the truth. They were allocated the following seats:

7B
8B
9B
10B
12E
14B
14C
14E
15B
19B
20B
21B
22B
23B
25C
29B
32B
33B

As you can see, apart from row 14, the group of 18 adults were scattered all over the plane and away from one another. Stranger still, most were allocated middle seats. I find it highly implausible that this happened at random.

Due to the seats allocated for the outbound flight, many of my parents' friends decided to pay the fee to select an allocated seat so that they could sit with their partner on their return flight. 

It disgusts me that the underhand tactics of some airlines has succeeded in unfairly lining their pockets. I do hope that you can do something about it. 

Please note: you only have permission to use this information if you remove my name and keep the data anonymous. 

Thanks,
Shane

The unpaid for adults were randomly allocated: 23e/29e/11e/12e.
There were enough spaces (had we paid to chose) so that we could have all sat together. I feel we were deliberately split up to encourage us to pay next time.

column13:
we travelled as 4 adults for my husbands 60th birthday. i always pay the price for allocated seating to ensure we sit together, with whichever airline i travel with. i usually look for the cheaper seats but this is usually about £5 each way per person but as i am a nervous flyer and my eldest son is on the autistic spectrum i pay the allocated seating price to ensure he sits with us as would agitate him if this was not the case.
i have already booked several abroad holidays this year and each time i have paid for pr booked seats. if i book the flights independantly then i am aware that i will be asked to pay extra to guarantee the party all sit together. i have just had to pay £10 each way per person to guarantee that me and my three girlfriends travel together with jet 2 in october this year. i also had to pay for guarnteed seating with thomas cook even though that was a package holiday to sorrento in september. i also paid extra for me and my husband to sit next to each other in june when we go to portugal with easy jet. this plus the additional costs for  hold baggage significantly impactson the cost of the flight and the holiday cost as a whole. i cannot comment on other airlines albeit i have used monarch and fly be in the past but again i assume they still charge for seating together. i cannot comment on the likes of ryan air as i will not use this airline having had a bad experience with them some years ago which I involved yourselves the CAA with and ended up getting my money back from my complaint once the airline knew that you were involved so I understand your importance in getting this issue of pre booked seating sorted for passengers on whichever airline they travel.

column13: Jet2 Holidays emailed 1 month before departure to offer online check-in. I tried to do so but received an error message saying ‘this option not available’. I phoned Jet2 who stated that all the online allocated seats are taken so check-in at the airport. Arrived at the airport on the day of departure to be told there were seats together but we had to pay for those otherwise the seats that had been allocated are separate. Asked why we couldn’t have the seats together the check-in clerk couldn’t answer and sent us to customer services. Clerk at customer services said our seats for both outbound and inbound flights were allocated on 12th January and they automatically split parties up unless you pay. We didn’t even have the option to pay! I asked what the policy on seating was and the clerk didn’t know. Policy clearly very confusing as I was told 3 different things. Also told we wouldn’t get seats together on journey home even if we paid or not!

column13:
When we checked-in online my wife and I were told we had been allocated seats several rows apart and that if we wanted to sit together we would have to pay extra. When we investigated this option we discovered a great many seats together were available. We contacted Ryanair via online chat to complain that it seemed mean-spirited of them not to have put us together when clearly there were many adjacent empty seats available. The chat agent was not prepared to discuss this and simply apologised for any inconvenience.
We had no option but to pay the extra to sit together. When we boarded the plane it was far from full and there many empty seats around us — so much so that there was an onboard announcement instructing passengers not to move from their allocated seats as this could affect  the weight distribution and jeopardise safety!
Our experience left no doubt in our mind that the method of seat allocation was a deliberate ploy to extract more money from passengers. 
We fed this  view back to Ryanair but received no response.

column13: BA return flights to Tenerife from London Gatwick. This is the first time ever we have had to pay. Normally we check-in exactly 24 hours before departure when we can choose seating for free. But for both outging and return flights, almsot all the seats had gone a week before the flight! It literally showed a few single seats available (some of them window seats - very odd as people like a window seat) very evenly spread across the plane, and two sets of two seats to choose from. Very reluctantly we felt compelled on each occasion to pay so that we weren't at opposite ends of the plane. We travel with BA every year to Tenerife and have NEVER experienced anything like this before, and strongly believe that something is going on (ie not just EVERYONE paying to reserve seats in advance). I'm thinking of asking passengers at the departure gate the next time I travel!

column13: On all occasions when booking with Ryanair we are unable to access the cheapest price offered for seats together even when booking 3 months in advance . When studying the seating plan the available seat next to mine was £17 to book my wife's seat no sign of a £4 seat when booking 3 months prior to flying . Two people sitting next to each other may on one flight pay £3 - £17 which is grossly unfair .

column11: None of these
column13: My recent experience on BA return flights (Club Europe) highlights how BA appear to be using this as a means to gain more revenue.  In the past, my husband and I have always been allocated seats together.  However, this time we were allocated different rows in both directions and ignoring our preferences of window/aisle seats that they have on their system. On the return flight this was 4A and 5C even though there were seats next to each other in Rows 6, 7 & 8.   We are BA Frequent Flyers (not for much longer based on this and other recent BA flight ‘experiences’) so we were able to change the seats 7 days before the flights.   When we phoned BA customer service regarding this they weren't interested despite their terms and conditions stating they will "do their best to sit you together".  Instead they tried to sell us seats for the long-haul flights we have booked for an extra charge of £400.  We have now reluctantly paid £200 for our outward flights, what we consider to be an extortion amount to guarantee seats together when we already have business class tickets.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: These were outward and return journeys with Ryanair Manchester/Carcassonne, on 11/9/17 and 18/9/17 respectively. We did not want to pay extra to sit together and previous experience with Ryanair suggested that some or all of us would be grouped together anyway.  However, despite checking in as soon as possible after on-line was available, all six of us were allocated seats in different rows, and five of us placed in the middle seat of three.  This inevitably meant that other pairs/groups checking in after us and being allocated seats randomly would be split up as well.  Conversations with those sitting either side of some of us revealed that they had been separated from others in their party, too.  My wife and I fly this route with Ryanair at least twice a year and we now feel compelled to pay extra to book seats so that we can sit together.  We have flown with Ryanair to Carcassonne for many years and have always previously been seated together without paying extra.  Something has definitely changed!

column11: We did not sit together because we didn’t know until we boarded that our seats were apart
column13: I assumed we would be sitting together (2 adults aged 78) because in many years of flying booking months ahead and 2-3 times a year with Easyjet, (the last being June 2017) we  were automatically sat together.  I booked December flight in March 2017. In Dec 2017, 3 weeks before flying I printed Easyjet's boarding pass,  astonished to see that my sister was one row behind at the opposite end of the row from myself.  The  seating plan at beginning of Dec showed 10+ rows both sides at the back half of the plane  not yet  allocated. Customer services  refused to change the seats until I paid (£22 pp for return journey). I paid and  complained to Easyjet on phone, was asked when I had booked (through their call centre with a voucher in March.) and was at once given 2 return seats each and refunded the paid money.  I am flying with Jet2 in March, not paying for seats together as too expensive, have photos of more than half the plane unallocated at beginning of Feb but told to wait to change till I print boarding pass and to print boarding pass as soon as available. Charging for seats together is a blatant way of making money if the seats are available at time of booking.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
We paid to guarantee seats together as Ryanair had changed their seat allocation policy approximately in May 2017, without informing passengers.
We have flown to Ireland with Ryanair for years, and because my Husband & I book on the same booking, even the randomly allocated seats were allocated within the same row & we were always sat together.
However, Friends travelled with Ryanair last May & it was the first time we were made aware of the new seat allocation process, and it appeared that passengers who had not pre-paid for allocated seats were invariably allocated seats in seat 'B' and 'E' (ie the middle seat) and were located several rows apart.
Allegedly, from a newspaper report I read, Ryanair had gone from using a seating algorithm which allocated seats laterally to allocating vertically instead (I cannot verify this, but anecdotal evidence appears to back-up the theory).
So, I have felt the need to book seats together since then, adding at least £8  per booking to my flights.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: None of these
column13: In fact our experience of travelling as a group and experiencing different seat allocation behaviour by Ryan Air started approximately 12 months ago. We are regular travellers to Athens from Stansted with Ryan Air (approx 3 times per year). Prior to 12 months ago we always checked in online and always without exception were automatically allocated seats that were contiguous. Approx 12 months ago we booked and checked in online and found that our seat allocation was widely dispersed in the aircraft. Although, this didn't cause too much of a complication we put this down to pure "bad luck". Last September (2017) we once again booked and checked in online expecting that Ryan Air's seat allocation would revert to it's normal sane behaviour and were amazed to experience the same wide dispersion of allocated seats. It is clear to me that Ryan Air have deliberately changed their algorithm to deliberately split up groups so that they will pay for a seat allocation. One of our party is suffering from dementure and we are now in a position where we are FORCED into paying extra in order to sit together when before this happened automatically. I'd urge the CAA to take action to ensure that the default behaviour for groups is that wherever possible they are seated together without requiring payment.

column3: More than 12 months ago, but within the last 2 years
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
The seating booking process is simply a ploy for all the airlines to make extra money.  It is a disgraceful practice that should be banned with immediate effect.  They are "selling" us something that used to a standard component of the ticket.  What happens to this money?
As I frequent flyer, I am struggling to identify where it is going.  For example, in 2015, Emirates did not charge for any seats.  However, over time, and by stealth, they have re-branded their seating areas, e.g. to standard, extra legroom, etc. and selling them for up to £75 per journey.  This is beyond extortionate - daylight robbery.  

Simultaneously, Emirates, together with other airlines, has steadily reduced their service on board e.g. reduced meals and refreshments on long-haul flights.

All airlines should be made to stop this practice.  Customers should be able to choose - for free - whether they would like to be seated together or apart from their family, friends or colleagues.  Or if travelling alone, where they would like to sit for personal reasons. 

It should be stopped because it is immoral and constitutes product mis-selling.  The ticket is promoted at X price which then inflates after purchase to XX price if you wish to be seated together or to choose if travelling alone.  The practice affects everyone, including those who are travelling with children, the elderly and the vulnerable who cannot or do not wish to be separated from their companions.  Also, those with health and mobility issues who wish to have an aisle seat and/or to be seated near the WC.

More seriously, this practice should be stopped because in the event of an accident THERE WILL BE SIGNIFICANT DELAYS in passengers exiting the aircraft because they will block the aisles trying to locate their loved ones and companions.  

Therefore, for practical, moral and safety reasons, this practice should be stopped with immediate effect. 

If the greedy airlines wish to make even more money out than they do already of their customers, despite the fact that they continue to extort money from us by stealth, e.g. refreshments, checked baggage, etc.  they should simply go back to the days when the headline price of the ticket included seat selection.

Their grubby efforts to steal money from customers by selling us seats that were previously free is having an adverse effect on air travel e.g. it takes longer to board as those who are separated spend additional time finding their seat and locating the other seat(s).  

This is in addition to the equally immoral,  illegal and unsafe practice of steadily reducing the seat pitch to cram as many seats into the aircraft as possible and charging for refreshments (even water - BA, Easyjet, Ryanair).

If you raise any concerns with the airlines about seating, they will send you a meaningless stock reply.  They do not care.  Their call centres are devoid of customer service and are designed to pickpocket you further by keeping you on the £££ line listening to toneless music for hours on end then cutting you off when you finally get through to a human based anywhere but the UK.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13: We booked our flights through a third party and found we were unable to book our seats in advance of check in although generally I do this to avoid the risk of the children being separated.  At online check in we were allocated seats in 4 separate rows each in a middle seat, with the youngest child allocated across the aisle and three rows away, I called customer services to request and pay for sitting together they said they could not do it and that Manchester airport would sort it out on arrival.  They couldn't do it and promised it would be sorted out at Dublin for the long haul leg, they couldn't do it either and said the cabin crew would sort it out at the plane.  I was very distressed by now feeling I had been lied to up to this point, the cabin manager was extremely helpful at the gate and told us he would try his best, he was able to seat myself and two children together in front of plane seats but my husband was seated in row 25.  In the end we were seated in an emergency exit and what they charge as preferred seating,  so probably better than a normal seat allocation, but it was unnecessary to inflict this additional stress on passengers at an already stressful time.  I learned two lessons, never book through a third party in spite of the minimal cost saving, never fly with Are Lingus again.  The return flight was with BA and although they did seat us together, the seat allocation was in the last row where we had a poor experience previously, I elected to change and pay for alternative seating at 45 pounds per person, 180 in total so lost the saving made by booking through he third party originally.  I will stick with direct airline booking in future, at least with Virgin Atlantic you know what your getting from the outset and their seat charging and allocation policy is easy to find.

column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
4 of us in a row of 6 seats and the other 2 seated approximately 10 to 15 rows behind.  Furthermore, the remaining 2 seats in the row of 6 were taken by a mother and son who in turn were seated separately from the father who was seated 3 rows in front of them.
Surely if you book as a family group the airline should seat you as a group.

I reported our concerns to Jet2 who basically told me that we were given the option of booking our seats for a small fee of £148.   This £148 was in addition to the £2155.40 we had already paid for our tickets.

Practically everyone I know who buy airline tickets expect to be seated together. 

 I am appalled that Jet2 seem to think it is ok to separate families on a holiday flight just because they haven't been pressurised into paying the exorbitant fees for allocated seats. 

If I buy tickets for a football match I don't have to pay extra to sit together
If I buy tickets for a train journey I don't have to pay extra to sit together
If I buy tickets for a ferry I don't have to pay extra to sit together
If I buy tickets for a bus/coach I don't have to pay extra to sit together

I don't expect the CAA to do very much about this as it is just another excuse for the Airline industry to make extra money.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: None of these
column13:
I have two recent flying experiences of being separated, both with Ryanair. On neither occasion did we pay to choose our seats, and on both occasions we were separated.

On the most recent occasion, we travelled from London Stansted to Verona. We were seated several rows apart, but when we boarded the flight it was immediately apparent that the flight was only half full, and both of us had been allocated the middle seat in an empty row. I believe that this demonstrates how Ryanair, despite their claim not to, are deliberately penalising passengers who do not wish to pay any additional money on top of the 'advertised fare' and are purposefully seating them in middle rows several rows apart.

On the first occasion, we flew from London Gatwick to Belfast. Here, the flight was nearly full, and many people were seated several rows apart (including my partner and I). As the flight reached cruising altitude, and the fasten seat-belt sign was turned off, this immediately signalled what can only be described as a farcical situation where a substantial number of people on the flight immediately moved around the cabin, swapping seats with others or taking up previously empty seats, so they could sit with the accompanying group. This appeared to me to be a very unsafe situation and one that could have been simply avoided had Ryanair not forced non-paying passengers to sit several rows apart.

I have every sympathy with low-cost airlines trying to maximise their incoming from passengers, and indeed have absolutely no problem with current baggage rules and the like. However, on the two occasions I have flown with Ryanair, it has been apparent that by refusing to pay any extra beyond the headline fare, many passengers are being deliberately penalised and forced to sit apart, even at times when flights are not fully occupied.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: None of these
column13:
I have flown with Ryanair to southern France for approx 5 years.  Until last year me and my husband have always been automatically allocated seats together when checking in online without the need to buy a seat.  In May 2017 we checked in online as usual and were very surprised to find ourselves sat separately, rows apart.  I researched this online and found other people were also suddenly having the same issue.  As a test when I checked in online for my return flight back to the UK, I viewed seat availability which you can do before buying a seat.  There were plenty of pairs of seats adjacent to each other.  I declined to purchase a seat so went through automatic allocation and was again given 2 separate seats, aisles apart despite there being plenty available together.  I viewed this as a deliberate change by Ryanair to force people into buying seats if they wanted to sit together.  I wanted to know why Ryanair weren't being upfront about this change to the algorithm for seat allocation when no seat purchase had been made, so I complained.  I received this reply which did not answer my question.

"Dear Mrs Chapman,  

Thank you for contacting Ryanair.

In relation to your recent correspondence I would like to inform you that we do our best to seat families together, however this will not always be possible. If you want to be guaranteed seats together we recommend that you purchase seats in advance. If you chose not to purchase seats and have been allocated seats which are not together, You will need to contact with our Reservation call center to purchase and re-allocated your seats."

column13: We were given tickets without any seats on the tickets on the booking online. column13: My partner and I booked a Ryanair flight to Alicante.  On the morning when we were able to use online check-in, I checked us both in.  I refused to pay the extra charge to choose our seats so they were randomly allocated.  We were both given middle seats in different rows despite seeing online that a large number of seats together were still available to purchase.  This was clearly a deliberate move to separate us and allocate us to middle seats as we refused to pay the extra unfair charge.  Surely this is piracy.  We were already told, sometime after booking, that we had to pay to bring our 10kg hand luggage on to the plane, which was a change of policy from the time we booked and a necessity as we were told we would no longer be able to take our laptops onto the plane as  hand luggage.

column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
We fly as a couple and we are pensioners 
We object to paying extra  to sit together as we are just a couple and we’ve already paid for our seats when we paid for the flights.  To accommodate a couple is much easier than accommodating a large group.  On the last three flights that  we’ve taken and on one tomorrow we have been separated.  I understand that they will prioritise people who are willing to pay extra BUT on ALL the flights we’ve taken with Ryanair when this has happened, there have not only been empty seats ( in twos) but also empty rows. Clearly we were separated deliberately and not because it was impossible to actually seat us together.  We think this is essentially little short of blackmail.  On our last flight there was one man lying down over three seats and the steward refused to ask him to let us sit together on that row even though WE were SEVEN rows apart.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
I flew Cologne/Bonn FR1592 to Manchester 03.01.2018 - 06:55 with my two children, who are 14 and 12.

When I checked in on the first possible day, the plane was only half allocated. 
We had to enter ages for all passengers - so the computer knew there were two children travelling.

When the computer site allocated us seats, they were apart - sprinkled all over the plane. This despite there being many free seats available that were three together in a row.

Obviously we had the option to pay extra to sit together, but I resent paying extra to sit with my children. It's just price-gouging - it doesn't cost an airline extra to set the computer algorithms to sit groups together. I also think that if you pay, it just encourages the airlines to continue to cheat us like this. If they don't make any money out of it, they will stop doing it.

When we boarded the plane, we took our allocated seats - I was about 10 rows back from the children. But there was a spare seat in the row behind one of them, so I sat there. When the person next to me saw what I was doing, he was sympathetic and said, "They did that to us, too - we're travelling in a group and they've sat us all over the plane."
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.140 Safari/537.36

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
I flew Cologne/Bonn to Manchester FR1592 on 03.01.2018 at 06:55.
I flew with my two children who are 12 and 14.

I checked in on the first day available.
I had to enter ages for all passengers, so the computer "knew" two of the passengers were children.

We were allocated three seats completely separately, sprinkled all over the plane.

Obviously it then tried to charge us to move seats. I looked at the seats still available, and there were many seats empty that were in a group of three.

But I didn't pay the extra to sit together. I don't believe it's acceptable to have to pay to sit with your own children on a plane. Sitting together doesn't incur any costs for the airline, so it's just money-gouging.

The flight is only an hour. And my children have flown many times before. But had it been a longer flight, I would have felt it necessary to sit near them.

I also don't want to encourage this behaviour. If nobody pays for this and the airlines can't make money out of it, they will stop doing it.

When we got on the plane, there was a free seat in a row behind one of the children, so I moved there.
A man in the seat next to me was sympathetic. He said: "They've done that to us as well - we're travelling in a group and we're all over the plane."

From talking to other passengers we get the impression that Ryanair purposefully split parties up to encourage people to pay the extra. On the outbound flight we were with Easyjet who sat us together despite not paying to do so. column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We did not all sit together despite paying extra to do so
column13:
Originally we booked to sit together for flight in and out, the outboard flight was changed and our seats reallocated.  We were told that we would be refunded for the extra we had paid.  This was not automaticaaly done and before settling the final payment we had to remind Virgin Holidays that the charge for seat allocations needed to be removed.

When boarding our outbound flight we checked that our (paid for) seats for the return flight were still confirmed and were reassured that they were. On check in for our retrurn flight we found out that our seats were all over the plane (over two levels), when questioning this we were told that the flight had been changed and as a result our seats reallocated.  This was not true.  This was the flight we had always been booked on.  We later discovered that an earlier flight had been combined with our flight and that was why are seats had been changed (even though we had paid for specific seats).  The check in desk were not interested in this and said we would need to take this up with customer services once we had returned. What was surprising is that there were plenty of seats available together where some of the party ended up sitting, even though we were now in different sections of the plane;  people were sitting upstairs and some downstairs.  Six of the party were seated in an area of the plane with no entertainment system and this is where the additional seats were.

On our return we had to contact customer services for a refund.  Not all our seats were refunded (the refund was given because we had no entertainment system for six of the passengers not for sitting in difefrent places to our booking). They would not refund two of the setas as they were extra leg room seatss and these incur an additional cost (similar to what we had already paid), even though they were not the setas we had booked.

column3: Within the last month
column11: None of these
column13:
Out of principle, I won't pay to sit with my daughter. Most airlines can perfectly manage to ensure those that book together can sit together, so I fail to see why this is beyond the capability of Ryanair, and other airlines that charge for this 'privilege'. My daughter is aged 12, and we have been allocated seats together in all other trips, but this time, I guess they consider her old enough to sit alone.

Upon online check-in, I saw that our seats were very much apart. In fact, they weren't even close. When I checked the Ryanair website for available seating, I saw that much better and closer seating could have been allocated for us - but, of course, they do this in order to increase the pressure on a passenger to 'give up' and buy seating.

I queried this with Ryanair via their Facebook chat, and was simply told that aisle and window seats were kept for those passengers that wished to pay extra to sit together. Middle seats were for those that weren't prepared to pay. In my opinion, for anyone that makes a flight booking with others, forcing them to sit separately is pathetic, outrageous and is downright price-gouging. A copy of this conversation has been kept, and I'm happy to let you see this, if you want.

I even checked to see what spare seats there were on the flight on the morning of travel. Assuming virtually everyone had checked in by then, seats were still available together and it would've been easy to ensure my daughter and I sat beside each other. However, nobody was willing / able to make the official change, and I was told to just move once on the plane. 

As you can guess, I wasn't the only one in this situation, and many others were scrambling around asking other passengers to move (along with their bags!), so that a party could sit together. This, I feel, delays the cabin being ready for take off and, frankly, must raise some safety concerns. 

Anyway, I'm happy to be contacted in any way, and hope you're able to bring an end to this ridiculous policy.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:58.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/58.0

I was travelling with my partner and wanted to sit together so I paid extra to be able to do so. Once on board there was a lady in my row (window seat) and her 5 year old daughter was allocated seat 7 rows behind her!!!! She was obviously very upset and would not stop crying. Staff couldn’t care less. They said the mom had the choice to pay extra to sit together. My partner swapped the seats with the little girl so she could be sitting with her mom. 
I travel with Ryanair 3-4 every year and if traveling solo, I always get a middle seat, even if there are then other seats available.

column13:
I am usually happy with the service that Tui (Thomson) offers, but have just had a very disappointing and frustrating experience regarding trying to force us to book and pay for seats unnecessarily.
I have booked a holiday to Majorca 31st March with 5 other friends and I am the lead traveller. My wife and I don't need to book seats, as my wife has a condition that allows her and myself to be offered free seats. However, just 2 of the other 4 travellers want to book their seats on the airplane. BUT, Tui are insisting that all 4 of them have to book their seats. They won't allow just 2 of them to book. I have spoken to them in the shop (where I initially booked the holiday), and they have confirmed that this is their policy. This means that either all 4 have to pay £30 extra each, or the two who would like to book their seats, take a big chance, and hope that they can choose reasonable seats when they book in on the day.
I consider this to be totally unreasonable and grossly unfair. What do you think?

column13: Firstly, the airline emails you to check in online but at this point it is not possible to check in unless you pay extra. Secondly, when you can check in online at no additional cost, the seats automatically allocated are apart, giving the illusion that all seats together are taken. However, if you then opt to pay extra for allocated seating it is often the case, even at a late stage, that there are plenty of available seats next to each other. Because of this it feels that this is a clear attempt to squeeze additional money out of passengers, and it never used to be this way.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
My wife and I have just checked in for a Ryanair flight from London Stansted to Malaga on 16/2/2018. We were offered many opportunities to select our seats - at a price. We declined these opportunities and were allocated seats 10e(middle) and 20e(middle). We were then offered yet another opportunity to purchase seats together if we were unhappy with the allocated seats. Looking at the seating map, it showed that seats 10d, 10f, 20d and 20 f  were all unallocated at that time. We were offered the opportunity to swap from 20e to 10d for £13 or from 10e to 20d for £11. We took the latter option.
It seems clear to me that Ryanair’s seating algorithm deliberately allocates the least attractive seating option it can find in order to pressurise passengers into paying for a change of seats.
In the last ten years, my wife and I have taken approximately 80 Easyjet flights and although we have never paid for allocated seating, we have NEVER been seated apart.

Good luck with your enquiry,

Regards,

Stephen Jameson

column11: None of these
column13:
I have booked a flight with Ryanair for my family, 2 x adults, 1 child and 1 infant.
Ryanair provides a free allocated seat to a child, but has demanding for either me or my wife to pay a seat reservation fee as one of us has to sit next to our child? I feel this is a rip off as it is a mandatory requirement from all airlines that a minor has to be accompanied by an adult, in our case one of the parents needs to be seated next to our daughter who is 3 years old. As this is a requirement why am I being charged/penalised for this? I don't have a preference where to be seated, there for I don't think this is acceptable, this is a blatant overcharge as technically I did not choose to sit next to my daughter, but was forced to do so due to the aviation rules/law and there for I should not be charged any extra fees for this, simply because I travel with a child?

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
Having elected not to pay the extra initially, the “random” booking seated one in the middle of the aircraft and one at the back, yet both of us were in otherwise empty rows. Clearly the booking system is designed to separate people travelling together. 
I consider having had to pay the total of £26 for 2 people to sit in, what were free seats, tantamount to theft or deception. 
The policy is absolutely disgusting. I know full well that the programme they use can be set to seat people on the same booking in the same row from the outset.

column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We did sit together
column13:
On the outbound flight we (the party of three) were seated together.  On the return flight however when we went to check in on-line only a few seats were showing as available (despite us logging on just after the 24 hour window opened).  We had no option but to select the remaining three seats that were available.  This was frustrating because we were all under one booking party so assumed we would be sat together.  For an overnight long-haul flight, this was somewhat distressing.
Upon arrival at the airport, we spoke to a member of staff who told us that we woud need to speak to the flight crew at the gate.  We arrived much earlier at the gate than required (thereby reducing our chances to relax prior to the flight) to ensure we were sat next to the desk.  When a member of the flight crew arrived, she was busy on the computer.  Allowing her time to finish, we went up and queried the party of three being sat in three seperate locations.  She advised that she had just moved us so we were sat together, and said she had done this for many people.  
When we got on the plane, someone came over and asked if we were all one party as he was sat away from his party and wanted one of us to swap.  We overheard numerous people on the plane discussing the issue (one party had become visibly distressed at the situation with the flight crew), and realised that it was a major issue.

column3: Within the last month
column11: None of these
column13:
1. I have flown with RyanAir on at least 20 occasions in the last 10 years, often as a group of four.
2. I have never opted to pay for seat allocation with RyanAir (nor with easyJet or Flybe)
3. Until Autumn 2017, our 'random' seat allocation with RyanAir always resulted in the group being in the same row, whether there two, three or four of us. It is almost impossible for this to be truly random. Further evidence of the lack of a 'random' allocation is that we never one ended up on a premium seat.
4. Since Autumn 2017, we have never been sat together
5. The most recent example was on Thu 18 Jan 2018, FR1070 from Valencia to Edinburgh, departing at 07:00. The flight was, at most, one third full. Our party of two was separated by 20 rows. Most of the rows in between were entirely empty.
6. I did not report any concerns to the airline - their policy of 'random allocation' was clearly; however, it had not applied at all in the past

I think I might be a good witness to a change in RyanAir's practice, since I generally keep a copy on my computer of all our boarding passes. I can show quite simply that a group with a single booking always used to travel together; never on the "good" seats, but always together.

I have another flight tomorrow with RyanAir, and even when downloading my boarding passes to a second iPhone, after checking in on the first to get yet another separated seat allocation, I am again offered the opportunity to sit together. This means that at least one of our seats has a space beside it.

NB: your question 8 above has no opportunity for a null response

It was also hard to complete Question 7 since our reason was "We had always sat together in the cheap seats without paying the airline even more". It's a slightly different spin on, "We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so" because the latter makes no mention of expectations.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
The CAA have a duty to ensure passenger safety is never compromised. Hopefully there are tried and tested measures in place so that if airlines wish to change their seating arrangement policies then the CAA is confident, from research already undertaken, that such changes do not present a greater risk to passengers.  For example, aircraft evacuation procedures should not be undermined due to random selected seating where a couple have been placed 13 rows apart.  If the CAA are not confident that safety standards are being maintained then changes to seating arrangement policies should not be allowed to be implemented until such time that vigorous research has been done. In a worse case scenario, passengers who refuse to pay extra to sit together and instead are seated 13 rows apart should not be placed in the awful, although admittedly rare, situation where there is an emergency on board which precludes the possibility of evacuation. The chances of this happening may be slim but it does happen. Nobody should ever have to hold the hand or say their last "goodbye" to a complete stranger. Sitting next to your partner should not be regarded as a paid for privilege.   
Ryanair's current random seating policy is not fair. The model being used is deliberately intended to split passengers up if they do not pay extra to sit together. It is a model which would not work well if it were applied to cinemas, theatres, sports arenas or even restaurants. There is no confusion as the CAA claim; passengers have to either pay extra to sit together or be assigned middle seats.   
On our recent outward journey with Ryanair my wife and I were allocated randomly selected middle seats which were 12 rows apart: for the return journey the randomly allocated middle seats were 13 rows apart. On this occasion our break was for only 4 days so we were able to check-in our return journey whilst still in the UK, which was within Ryanair's time limit, but if our break had been for 5 days or longer then our check-in for the return journey for random selected seating would have to be made abroad. 
Ryanair's current random selected seating policy is not transparent. Whilst Ryanair call centre  staff may not have been instructed to say they operate a deliberate policy of splitting couples up, any queries regarding middle seat allocation are met with the same scripted response, namely passengers can pay extra if they wish to sit together.
Ryanair do not need to be publicly open about their seating policy; the model they use for seating allocation says it for them. Ryanair must know approximately how many couples will be travelling on any particular given flight, and the model they use must be able to determine the percentage of that figure they need to obtain from couples prepared to pay to sit together in order to maximize  their profits. It should then follow that there will be a small percentage of randomly allocated seating where seats are next to each other but Ryanair does not readily indicate how these seats can be freely booked. 
Ryanair's check-in page exclaims "avoid the middle seat", as if it were some form of contagious illness. It would be interesting to know the extent to which this is contradicted by the number of instances where couples who have paid to sit together include one of them sitting in a middle seat.  Furthermore, on board announcements now state that passengers should not move from their allocated seats so as not to disturb weight distribution throughout the aircraft. This is a ridiculous situation especially where there might be two empty seats together but the airline has not done enough sufficiently beforehand to allow passengers to book them.
Ryanair and all other carriers know there are a limited number of choices available to passengers travelling to certain destinations. Passengers, like ourselves, have paid months in advance to book seats and those monies are already gaining interest for the airlines.  
Customer satisfaction is not an airline's main priority. We have booked three further flights this year with Ryanair and, after our recent experiences, feel we are in a much better position to consider all options .
Although this opportunity to comment on Ryanair's random seating allocation policy has been welcomed concerns have been raised by others for over a year which should have been addressed earlier.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko

I did point out to Norwegian customer complaints our concerns but they were refuted and we were advised to come early to the airport if we did not want to sit apart, however there was no guarantee if we arrived earlier then the flight we may be sitting together, i tried on many occasions explained a gesture would be appreciated but was refused point blank that we must book to guarantee sitting together, which I feel was inappropriate when travelling with a small family. I asked for complaint to be escalated however again this was refused and they closed my complaint without my consent or taking the matter further, poor customer service experience. The whole experience dealing with Norwegian has left a Savoury taste in our mouths  and are seriously considering whether to book with  them again and if we had an option, which we also tried, is to cancel our flights and book with another carrier, after raising our concerns, which was refused as a non refundable tickets. Again another issue is that the reason for cancelling is for poor customer experience and not being able to sitting without paying for the privilege .

column13: We've travelled regularly with Ryanair for many years and have always sat together until recently, and  since our holiday to Tenerife the year before last, we have been separated on every flight, including regular trips between Ireland and Liverpool. On some flights we have been lucky enough to swap with other people, but not always. It is blatant what they  are doing and everyone knows it. On our last return trip from Tenerife I was sitting next to a man whose wife was sitting near my husband, and another couple were also split near us so we all swapped and managed to sit together. It turned out that many more people had been separated too. Ryanair are doing this to force more money from its passengers. On that particular trip I took ill and nearly passed out so it was fortunate that I managed to swap. I would have been mortified sitting next to a complete stranger and having to lean on them.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
The answers to your questions may not be relevant because ultimately we solved the issue by contacting the company.  Our situation was that we were flying with the following:
4 x Adults over 18, one of whom had never flown before and was nervous
3 x Children of ages 6, 7 and 10, two of whom were fully documented and diagnosed as Autistic
1 x Baby under 1 year
The visit was to take the children to visit their great grandparents for, most likely, the last time due to the failing health of the said grandparents.
The flight was chosen as it was the most economical for a family, especially during school term.
The cost of chosen seats was found to be an additional £11 per person each way and seemed to also include children, thus and additonal £77 each way.  The cost was not shown until after all booking information had been completed.  When contacting the company, they could not seem to understand that the children being seated away from one parent would have caused distress which would have also, likely, disrupted other passengers.
After a number of telephone conversations and exchange of documentation to support the diagnosis of Autism, it was agreed to seat us together without charge, however the whole process was troubling and made the option to travel by air, as a family or group a much less favourable option.  I believe that the costs advertised from the start should include the cost of an allocated seat and that it is assumed that groups, especially families will want to sit together.  Reductions could be offered to those who are happy to give up their set seat

column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
I booked the flight on line and selected not to have seats pre-booked as it was all extra cost.

When I saw the seats that were allocated automatically by the system there were 2 seats together at the front of the aircraft and one at the back. There were closer seats to the front available for the single passenger allocated to the back so I tried again the have the seats automatically allocated. I thought that the system could recognise that we were one party and that they would at least seat us at the closest point possible. This was not the case.

I emailed Tui to complain as whilst I appreciated that we may not be seated together I would at least expect out of duty of care of mere customer service to be seated at the closest available seat to the rest of the family. There were two adults and my son who was 10 yrs at the time.

I have worked overseas as an overseas resort manager and it was company policy to seat our customers as close together as possible - especially families. Tui did ensure that my son was with one adult however I suspect the system was programmed to ensure this.

Before confirming seats and the flight I tried going back into the system many times to get other (automatically allocated) closer seats allocated however there was no change. I called the helpline to see if I could be allocated the seat about 5 rows behind my partner and child instead of at the very back of the aircraft but was told I would have to pay.  

All this was documented in my email to Tui and below is the reply I received. pls note it is addressed to my partner as I think he was the lead name:

	
Booking Reference:1305849-S15
Case Reference:CO-134795
Issue Date:04/09/2015



Dear Mr. Galiatsatos,

Thank you for your recent feedback with regards to your holiday experience with Thomson and First Choice, I am sorry to hear of the issues that you have raised.

I understand that when you had checked in you had two seats together and one seat a considerable distance away which I can appreciate would have been concerning to you which I am sorry for however, without using the select your seat option Thomson cannot guarantee that you will be sat together.

I can see that there was a seat closer to where the two seats were situated however, this would have been calculated on how busy that particular flight was and is at random when people do not pay.


I appreciate this would have been frustrating also as if you asked upon checking in at the airport you may have received them for free however, this cannot be guaranteed unless you were to pay the select your seat supplement.


Thank you again for your feedback, I hope that other than this that you enjoyed your holiday experience. I am sorry for the inconvenience that this would have caused.


Yours sincerely,
Abbi Keenan

After Travel Customer Support Advisor
AfterTravelCS email: aftertravelcustomersupport@tuiuk.com

CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE & DISCLAIMER This message, together with any attachments, is for the confidential and exclusive use of the intended addresses(s). If 



We ended up paying for our seats so we could be seated together.

Best regards,
Karen

Karen Bolton
07760168291

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
We are always book our flights on the same PNR. Ryanair have consistently seated us as far apart as possible, even when the seatmap shows that pairs of adjoining seats were available at the time of checking-in.

Furthermore, as soon as the free seating allocation was completed, Ryanair attempted to up sell adjacent seats to us - an offer which we did not take up.

The seat allocation algorithm used by Ryanair is not random. It is clearly designed to separate groups of passengers in an attempt to generate ancillary income.  

I appreciate that it is in Ryanair's commercial interest that their headline fare always appears at the top of  search results. That headline fare would appear much further down the list if all of the ancillary fees (including seat selection) were included at the outset.

Our flights are generally less than three hours in duration so it is not essential that we are seated together. However, Ryanair's policy positively discriminates against families and those with special needs who have no option but to pay the additional fees if it is essential that they are seated together. 

Customers have quickly seen through this attempt at blackmail. Once on board, voluntary seat swapping takes place, groups get to sit together and excessive fees are avoided.

Thank you for investigating this predatory sharp practice.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
I have recently read an article concerning the above topic and would be interested in your comments on my experience.

At the moment I am in Buenos Aires and will be returning to the UK tomorrow on a British Airways flight. The outbound flight was to Santiago from Heathrow last month. My wife and I travelled business class and booked the flights last April. I was astounded that despite paying a premium price for the seats that there was a seat allocation charge if I wanted to book specific seats. As it turned out, my wife was on a completely different row to me after we used the free on-line check-in facility and we were told there was no scope to alter this when we dropped off our luggage.  Additionally, we were both surrounded by single passengers who could have been moved if requested. I am assuming that the same will apply when I check-in for the return flight.

In contrast, last year we flew with Singapore Airlines to Auckland. Again, we booked the flights about 10 months ahead of the trip and we knew exactly where we were to sit at that time.

My suspicion is that BA, along with the budget airlines, are fleecing passengers by charging for seat allocation. Your investigation into the topic interests me and I will be challenging BA when I return home about their practice.

column3: Not Answered
column11: Not Answered
column13:
Last April I booked a holiday with First Choice on booking reference 3877381.  Prior to travel we decided we would book seats to make sure we sat together but for some reason that day we could not do this online.  We phoned and First Choice offered us a window seat and the middle seat which was fine – we paid the fee.  On travelling we were given the seats we booked but no window.  On my return I sent various emails back and forth asking why I paid for a window seat which was quoted to me by one of their employees and never received one.  This went on for 5 months as when you contact the After Sales Team you have to wait for 28 days on a response.  I told them I didnt select my seats I was offered on the phone a window seat and middle to which I agreed to pay for but never received.  They totally blanked me and said I was not guaranteed a window seat.  

 

Surely this is just another step to add costs for consumers and not deliver – to me a window seat is a window seat.

 

To date which is 10 months on I still dont have an answer as when I asked who regulated them they just stopped communicating.

 

Wondering if this is correct and if so can this be added into your survey – thanks

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
Our family of three travel regularly with Ryanair. On every one of the 100 or so flights taken between 2006 and spring 2017 we were allocated seats together without paying extra. Since spring 2017 we have been separated on every one of the eight flights taken.

 My main concern with Ryanair's change of seating algorithm is one of safety: should there be occasion to evacuate the aircraft in an emergency, will a husband in row 30 head promptly for the rear exit, or will he try and move forward against the flow in order to assist his wife in row 12? Will a mother in row 16 immediately leave via the over-wing exit, letting her 13 year-old child in row 24 fend for himself? Unlikely.

I understand that it is not always possible to seat travelling companions/families together on every flight, but I believe that airlines should be obliged to do their best to do so in order to prevent chaos during an emergency, which could cost lives.

We raised this with Ryanair at the time and they reiterated that by not paying a few we had "accepted random allocation". 

Our view is that we had not been randomly a located seats but instead had constructively been allocated seats that would lead us to pay the fee.

Other passengers that we spoke to had been allocated seating in the same way and so in practice passengers swapped amongst themselves to move children to their parents.

We accept that we did not pay for 4 seats together or for a specific location but would expect seats to he reasonably close or at least 2 plus 2 or for the young child to be with a parent with other adults and older children sat elsewhere.

column13:
I/We have travelled with this airline for years without any problem until recently. The airline deliberately programmes it's system to deliberately split up the people travelling together. Furthermore they allocate the middle seats first until all of the middle seats are occupied. On this last flight we boarded the aircraft last and noticed that there were several rows of empty seats (the flight was not full) so we sat together. We were then asked to move and take up our allocated seats because of trim problems with the aircraft.
then after everyone was seated the crew asked 3 other passengers who were seated beside me to move towards the row of seats that we had been moved from ....because of trim problems !  This is an absolute joke. Purely to attempt to extract a few ££'s from us.

column13:
Monarch went into liquidation so we did not fly. The point I would like to make is  I have just booked two flights with Jet2 but refused to pay to sit together. I feel I am being held to ransom as the allocation of 2 vacant seats can be done at the time of booking. This is becoming a common practice amongst airlines to raise extra revenue & have no other reason as far as I can see.

To purchase extra leg room is acceptable but to have to pay to sit next to travelling partners has to be outlawed. Seats should be allocated on a first come first served basis not as a preferential treatment. Do first class or business class passengers have to pay the extra fee to sit together? if not this is surely discrimination on the basis of ability to pay.

column3: More than 12 months ago, but within the last 2 years
column11: We did not sit together because we didn’t know until we boarded that our seats were apart
column13:
The flight in question was a return leg at the end of a holiday. The flight was on 30 May 2017 leaving Seattle/ Tacoma airport on an overnight flight to Heathrow. I paid in full for the return flights £5413.44 in Sept 2016 (6 months early) . Indeed the booking agent "Royal Caribbean cruises " told BA that I specifically wanted to be sat next to my wife on the flights due to her being nervous. BA stated as long as I paid in full immediately for the flights I could choose my seats immediately. What BA failed to mention was that there would be an additional fee of £77 pp each way, I found out a few days later when trying to choose seating.  On boarding at Seattle my wife and 2 other couples were split up as we had not paid the extra surcharge. By simply moving of a few passengers we managed to get 2 couples sat together.  Safety risk of sitting next to a stranger on overnight flight as has been proven with a rise in sexual assaults on women. BA information misleading.  
BA viewpoint when I complained about this and other issues stated the International carriage by Air regulations and Montreal Convention applies and they are not liable for misrepresentation or breach of contract  under Domestic law . In addition BA state "The  BA  website  is  advertising  material  and  the  representations contained therein are not contractual terms." So BA can advertise what they  want they do not have to deliver it.  I took county court action against BA  for a number of failings not delivering what they advertised. The court ruled that I had no claim as on presenting a ticket for a flight at check in the Montreal Convention applies and BA are have only limited liability for Injury/loss/damage and delay. Airlines know this and this is why they are so arrogant.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/7.0; rv:11.0) like Gecko

When I went through the booking process I noticed that we were not sat together, but in fact twenty rows apart. I went through the booking process and then raised the issue to Ryanair suggesting perhaps they could change either my wife's or my own seat for one next to the other or both of us to a pair of available seats. I was told this would not be possible without an extra payment. I found this frustrating since there were numerous pairs of seats available to book at a price, which made it appear as a money-making mechanism.
When we embarked, we duly found plenty of pairs of seats unoccupied, confirming in my mind that it would have been possible to achieve this if the booking algorithm were more tuned to sit pairs/groups of travellers together. Disappointing customer service experience when we raised this with Ryanair directly, suggesting that we pay for the opportunity to sit together.

column13:
I booked a cruise with Celebrity from Miami over New Year for myself, wife, daughter and granddaughter (14). Celebrity booked 4 seats with BA from Heathrow but outward flight was with American Airlines.
We received flight details and the seats were all separate even though booked together.
I tried to change seats on American Airline website but came up, as £78 each seat.  I phoned the airline as there were seats within the same section that were free but still insisted on £78 to change seat so we could sit together, which I had to pay in order for us to sit together.
The return flight with BA , I paid £32 to book a seat before they were allocated as I imagined the same situation again where the airline would split the party in order to make the customer pay extra for sitting together.
I have sent this following an article in the Daily Mail on Saturday
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (iPad; CPU OS 11_2_5 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/604.5.6 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.0 Mobile/15D60 Safari/604.1

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
I was seated with my 9 year old son, but otherwise all members of the party were all separated from each other, with individuals at the front of the plane, at the back and over the wing.  It was clearly Ryanair policy to split us up since we hadn't paid for 'priority boarding' rather than just chance.

SAFETY ISSUE: During the flight it struck me that rather than just being an attempt to get an extra £50 from a family of customers, the policy it was actually unsafe.  My 14 and 17 year olds are fairly independent, but in an emergency where the plane needed to be evacuated or the oxygen masks were deployed, they would look to their parents to know what to do, and we would definitely want to see they are safe.  In these dangerous scenarios all family groups that have been split up would look after each other and would try to fight their way past each other, up and down the plane if necessary, to check all members of their group are safe.   This could cause fatal delays in evacuation during a fire.

Whilst I find it unpleasant, I support Ryanair's right to drive down prices at the cost of some comfort, and give others the chance to buy back that comfort.  This seating policy, however is clearly unsafe and I'm afraid the CAA should step in to ensure groups are generally sat together.

There are enough groups of different sizes to allow all groups to be sat together and this is what the CAA should recommend on safety grounds.  The airlines will still have the opportunity to offer quieter seats at the front, or ones with more leg room over the wing exits for a price.

column3: More than 12 months ago, but within the last 2 years
column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
I think this is a great example for you of some bad practice going on at Virgin Atlantic.  Well worth investigating.  

The three of us (one married couple and a single friend) did want to sit together on this long haul flight but didn’t really want to spend the extra money.  I monitored the seat availability running up to the 24 hours before departure and noted that not many seats had been reserved so I felt confident of being able to select 3 seats together (or at least 2).  Minutes after check-in opened, 24 hours before departure, I logged onto the Virgin website to choose our seats.  I was very surprised to find we had been dotted around the economy cabin and that it was impossible to change the seat allocation given to us.  

When we got to the airport the next day I queried this and was told it was probably because we were a group of three and the system probably couldn’t find three seats together. I queried why it would just let us choose to change at least one seat. No real answer.  Have to say I was a bit pissed off and didn’t really believe the answer I was given. 

Anyway we boarded the plane - flight VS300 on the 22/3/2016 LHR to Delhi (booking reference EK6G1W) and I sat in my allocated seat 46A.  My wife and our friend were several rows in front and behind respectively.  As the plane filled up I chatted to the person in seat 46C and eventually it looked like most passengers had boarded and seat 46B was unoccupied. So I said to the passenger in seat 46C that it looked like we might have a bit of extra space which was nice, but also said that if it remained empty would he object if my wife, who had been allocated a seat elsewhere, came and sat in it.  He said that would be fine and then added that he was convinced that it would be empty because when he had checked the online system just after it opened he had been automatically allocated that middle seat, and when he got to the airport he asked if he could change his seat and they did from 46B to 46C.  I then asked him why he hadn’t done that online the previous day and he said it would not let him. 

I concluded that all three of those seats could have automatically been allocated to us at the time Virgin do their automatic seat allocation, but instead they deliberately spread us around the cabin.  They also then did not allow us to change our automatically allocated seats when it would appear that we should have been able to do so. 

Because of this experience we reluctantly paid the extra to sit together on our return flight.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: None of these
column13:
This is more about the unknown family sitting adjacent to us.  

We were booked on flight BA43 from LHR to CPT departing 31/12/17 on booking reference 4M7G52.  Since it was New Year’s Eve we had paid for two seats together which we got and used.  Can’t find our seat numbers but we were in the right two seats of the 4 in the middle of a 747 roughly in the middle of the plane.  If the 10 seats left to right were say a,b,c - d,e,f,g - h, j, k  then we were in f & g. 

When we boarded we took our seats and all was fine.  It was a full flight with lots of families with young children/babies.  As I recall it the lady in seat (I assume) H had a small baby on her lap.  Her husband appeared to be in seat K and an independent passenger was in seat J.  I saw them having a discussion and the independent lady in seat J swapped with the man in seat K so that he and his wife and baby could all be together.  Everyone was happy.   I can only assume that the family had not paid in advance to sit apart and therefore had taken a gamble on being together which failed. I can also only assume that the single traveller had not paid in advance to select a middle of three seats - why would you!   So again it looks like BA had purposefully and unnecessarily separated the family with a baby to encourage then to pay to reserve a seat in the future.

column13:
I am convinced that Ryanair deliberatly seperated my wife & myself in order to "encourage" us to pay more to ensure that we sat together. On the flight, there were a number of other couples who had the same experience, so that there was no clear reason why we were all separated at check-in.
The cabin crew did try to relocate all the seperated couples on boarding but  clearly were very harrassed and under pressure in attempting to achive this.     

In my opinion, this is another example of budget airlines in general and Ryanair in particular, treating customers as a means of squeezing every last penny out of them and viewing customers as "the enemy"!

column13:
Not sure if this is applicable but it is sort of about getting the best seats available.  

We regularly fly BA and often use Avios points to do so but find it close to impossible to get anything other than economy seats and sometimes that is difficult.  I know the number is restricted etc and that is the reason given.   However I also know that on quite a few of these flights airline staff (past, present and related to) get free or very cheap seats mostly in classes superior to economy.  So my questions are i) why are the staff prioritised better than the customers, and ii) given that they benefit a better seat (they could have had mine) are they not receiving a taxable benefit which the HMRC should tax them on?

Obviously my point above applies where I had been a full fare paying passanger or an Avios paying passenger.

column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13:
This is the second time in I have now had this from Ryanair. We travelled to Warsaw last week. We didn't want to pay extra to sit together so we were not too fussed, however, on both journey's, the "algorithm" that proclaim to use obviously does not work. We were seated apart from each other, even though my partner had a completely empty seat next to her. And around us on the aircraft there were other empty seats. 

Last August we travelled back from Madrid, Ryanair again. We were sat apart again. We both had a window seat and my partner was sat in the row in front of me. Next to me were two gents, and their third friend was sat next to my partner with a spare seat. This clearly shows that the "algorithm" deliberately separates people to collude them to pay extra for the pleasure of sitting with their friends and family. 

This is has only recently started to happen. The seating system up until about a year ago tried its best to sit people together. Having flown with numerous airlines, so far it only appears to be Ryanair, however, it's very frustrating to see and I'd very much like the CAA to clamp down on the ludicrous practice.

The week prior to departure I went to online check in to discover that the airline had split the party by allocating my grandchild's mother and I to different seats away from the others.
