column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
I wrote to the CEO of Thomson on 2 Nov 2015 as follows:

Dear Mr Burling,
I am sorry to tell you that my view of Thomson has suffered a serious setback. I came away feeling the victim of sharp practice and manipulation for the sake of a few pounds in the Thomson coffers. I want you to think of this manipulative practice in terms of the damage it does to your image and customer relations. Is it really worth what you might gain financially?

Yesterday evening I went through the online check-in for flight TOM7260 from East Midlands to Tenerife South, just 36 hours before the scheduled flight time. I was presented with the cabin plan showing the two seats allocated to me and my partner. They were separated by the aisle. All other seats were shown as unavailable, apart from two pairs one on the starboard side and the other on the port side. When trying to select either pair I was presented with a charge of around £10 per seat. I felt I was being manipulated and pressured into paying for seats together, even at this late stage. Firstly, I felt I was being treated like a fool by being shown an apparently fully checked-in cabin plan with only 6 seats left, that is simply unbelievable! Secondly, I was deliberately allocated split seats when their were pairs available. The return flight had exactly the same cabin plan and seat allocation. This was an attempt to force a few extra pounds out of my pocket and into yours just so we could sit together. There comes a time when seats should be allocated fairly, even though the customer has not chosen to pay extra to select them. I have much experience with other airlines and have never before faced such sharp practice. Do you try the same trick at the check-in desk? 
From my reaction, you should be able to tell the damage it does to your image. Can you really afford to inflict such self harm? This practice is a further example of what is popularly known as "Rip Off Britain". In fact, I could possibly alert the BBC television programme to this experience.
I urge you to consider changing this practice for the sake of the Thomson image.

Yours sincerely,

Brian Bonsall

I also wrote to the CAA complaining of this dubious practice on 15 November 2015. Displaying a completely full cabin, apart from six available seats was false pretences. I have flown with Thomson about six times since and the story is always the same. I argued that their seating algorithm was deliberately designed to separate people who do not pay extra. With three seats either side of the aisle, statistically 66% of couples will naturally sit together. It requires a deliberate act to separate couples. I have been flying regularly for more than thirty years and it is only in recent times I have found it hard to sit with my partner without money being demanded. I am not alone in resenting this practice and it is certainly contradictory to good customer service.

I received a phone call from the CEOs office but it was full of excuses and obfuscation. I had my say but nothing changed. 

I am pleased to see that the CAA is investigating. I just hope the CAA has the will to act.

This is my letter to the CAA: 15 Nov 2015

From my recent experience,and what I see other people are saying, I would like to know which is the best body to bring pressure to bear on Thomson Airways to make it review its policy on seat allocation.
I have read the CAA guidelines in which it says "passengers should not be required to pay extra for a particular seat". I understand the difference between "requiring" and "volunteering". This means that giving passengers 90 days to choose to pay to prebook seats can be seen as a voluntary payment and not against your guidelines. Although Thomson's publicity and advice suggests the need to prebook, and pay extra, in order that couples, or families, can sit together. This, despite the fact that there is a 66% likelihood that couples will have to sit together, when there are 3 seats either side of the aisle anyway.
Where Thomson's policy and procedures become dubious is when it comes to the point, 7 days before departure, that online checkin opens. There is evidence to show that Thomson Airways computer program for seating allocation is programmed to allocate split seating in order to force "voluntary" payments out of passengers who require to sit together. So their publicity advising people to pay to sit together is reinforced by their computer program which deliberately separates couples when passengers have chosen not to pay. 
Just 36 hours before the departure time, I logged in to do online check in. I had chosen not to pay for seat allocation during the previous 90 days. I was staggered to be confronted with a cabin plan showing two seats allocated to me on either side of the aisle and only 4 other available seats in pairs on either side of the aircraft. Exactly the same cabin plan was displayed for the return journey two weeks later, which I found too much a coincidence to be believable. On clicking on either of the available pairs of seats a pop-up showed the additional charge of £9.50 per seat. I felt this to be misrepresentation and deception, in an attempt to force me to pay extra for available seats. In addition, I found that at least 20% of passengers still check in at the desk; by my asking a check in clerk. So on our flight of 189 seats there were 21 spare seats anyway and at least 38 still to check in at the desk plus others who would have done online check in after me This means I was shown a fictitious cabin plan when I did online check in. There would have been at least 60 seats still unallocated, not just 6!
I would like to see Thomson's made to change their policy, so that 7 days before departure they give up further attempts at manipulating their customers. They should be made to show true cabin plans with true  availability of seats and freedom for customers to select seats from those remaining, with no further attempt to extract extra charges by misrepresentation and manipulation. This evidently is contrary to your guidelines. I have a feeling that their current practice of displaying a false cabin plan is misrepresentation and borders on the fraudulent. It would surely attract a severe reprimand if attempted by most retail traders.
I have written to the CEO of Thomson Airways, who gave my letter to one if his staff who gave me a reply which did nothing to show they understood, or wanted to understand, the serious issue I raise. Hence, I am writing to you.

Brian Bonsall

column13:
BA took our money to  ensure that we sat together (and have so far refused to refund it) despite them forcing the cancellation of the flight.

 A week before travelling I found that they had changed our connecting flight (2 leg journey) to 3 hours BEFORE we would arrive at the intermediate airport (ANU).  They refused to arrange an alternate ongoing flight  on the same day or the following days leaving me to sort out the mess - the only options they gave  being 

1.to make our own alternate arrangements  for our onward travel and accept a refund of 'that leg only' PROVIDED THAT we completed the rest of the booking (i.e. the FULL return leg from Tortola -EIS to ANU & LGW) as per the booking. 

2.Cancel the booking in full and have a refund for the flight cost. 

I had no choice  but to cancel and am still awaiting my refund for that

The replies I have had so far re asking for a refund of the seat payments for the trip are that they wont pay because I cancelled the flight. Apparently the microseconds of administration their computer took to allocate the seats and collect my money is a cost they need to recover and the fact that they forced the cancellation is irrelevant!

It is more or less accepted by us customers that when dealing with many airlines it really is a caveat emptor situation where they will rip you off for extra money wherever they can. This though is the worst example of lack of customer care I have ever experienced in 40 years of travelling.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
For the last 10 years we have flown with Ryanair (London Stansted to Alicante), approx 5 times a year.  Up until May 2017 we always sat together even though we did not purchase seats. (Until then, it seemed to be Ryanair's policy to sit you together although they could not guarantee it, when you had a free seat allocation.)
On our last flight in December, we were allocated seats 5E and 17B.

From May 2017 we found that Ryanair allocated you two seats that were not together, but offered to change then for a fee (£6 -£17) if you wanted to sit together.
Also Ryanair had reduce the time before flying that you could checkin for a free seat, down to 4 days in advance of the flight.

On checking in for the subsequent 5 flights since then, I have checked seat availability (for free checkin) from from the four days down to the day before the flight. I have seen that even when there are several complete rows of seats available we have been separated each time. Also the Centre seats of complete rows are allocated first, which then ensures the last people to check in are always seperated. 

We have seen other groups separated: 
ie.  Families with two year old child separated, with Mother on the front row and Father and child back in the 30 rows.
Person with a physical disability would have been separated from the rest of the family, but for other passengers agreeing to swap seats to enable them to be together. 

I emailed Ryanair customer service in 13th July last year and had the following response. 

"In relation to your recent correspondence we inform you that, we haven’t changed the random seat allocation policy. More and more of our passengers are taking our reserved seats (from just £2) and these passengers overwhelmingly prefer aisle and window seats which is why people who choose random (free of charge) seats are more likely to be allocated middle seats.

The reason of the appearance of empty seats is that these are more likely to be selected by reserved seat passengers, many of whom only check-in 24 hours prior to departure. Since our current load factor is 95%, we have to keep these window and aisle seats free to facilitate those customers who are willing to pay for them.

This is entirely a matter of customer choice. We are not trying to force people to pay for reserved seats. We are very happy to facilitate any customer who wants a free of charge random seat but at the same time, we do our best to facilitate customers who are willing to pay for a reserved seat.

Please accept our renewed apologies for the inconvenience encountered on this occasion."
I cannot see that most customers prefer the aisle or window seats when they book, as, when you look round, the majority of passengers  seem to be Couples, Families or groups!

The strangers (other passengers) who are unfortunate to be seated next to us will not enjoy the experience but his own family would be tollerant to his needs and used to his disability. The policy virgin operate is awful and now that this is known we will never book with this airline again. I was even told over the phone that “ if they let us off the seating charge everyone would want an autistic child just for the perks”! If the discount is not available on that flight you will be charged the difference between the lowest price on the flight and their allocated sum. Disgusting to say the least. Being 6 of us I had the curiosity to test the normal allocation of seats...none of us got seats even close to each other.

column13:
Although we did not pay the extra to sit together, we did end up sitting together because several couples and families, inc ourselves, swapped seats to enable the family groups to sit together (primarily). This then enabled the others involved in the swap, to sit next to their partners/travelling companions. Obviously the cabin staff saw what was occurring so it follows the airline is neither bothered where people sit, or the fact that if there was an attempt to identify who was sitting where, in an accident, they would have no idea.
On a previous flight we also swapped seats with another couple to sit next to each other

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
Free allocation of seats was not available until 4 days before flight.  4 days before flight I checked in my wife and I (same surname)  to discover for our outward flight we were not seated together and that we were both in seats with no availability on either side of us.  This meant that to sit together we had to pay for two seats to be moved, despite the fact that there were rows nearby with 3 available seats. (I have a picture of the screen showing this).  The same was repeated for our return flight. This added  well over £20 to our flight costs.  Ryanair claims that the seats are allocated randomly, but in our case because were going for the free seat allocation we were split up in such a way that to sit together we had to pay for 4 seats in total.
In my opinion this is not random allocation, but clearly engineered to maximise money for Ryanair.  The CAA should clamp down on this.  We have travelled with Easyjet and Jet2 and in each case we are allocated seats together without paying.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/63.0.3239.132 Safari/537.36

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
Ryanair website allows you to pre book seats 4 days in advance at "No extra cost". What it doesn't tell you is that you will be allocated random seats on the flights and once allocated we would have to pay £20 each way to move from the seats allocated in order to sit together.   I raised the issue with the Ryanair  online chat facility but the standard answer returned to each of my questions was " Company Policy". At the time of making the seat reservation the flight was no more than 50% allocated. Many of the passengers on both flights were sat away from family or friends causing numerous minor issues of people sitting in seats with travelling companions rather than allocated seats. Causing cabin staff to get involved.
This policy is not only a rip off it will lead to, in my opinion, issues on flights in the summer to holiday destinations where passengers will have consumed alcohol prior to boarding.

column3: More than 3 months ago, but within the last 6 months
column11: We did sit together
column13:
This was our first flight with Ryanair. We have flown many times with EasyJet.
Initially when booking the flight I opted to take the seats suggested at check-in.  I have always done this with EasyJet and we have always been given seats together.
Ryanair allocated us a middle seat of 3 in row 10 and a middle seat of 3 in row 20! So that we could sit together I had to move one of us which cost £11.  There were plenty of seats available all round us so this allocation was clearly a way to extort additional money from us!  It's a pity because the flight was very good value (even with the extra £11), on time and the staff were really nice so without this seat booking idiocy I would have had a much higher opinion of the airline than expected from their adverse publicity.

column3: Within the last month
column11: None of these
column13:
The Chief Executive of the CAA states airlines are entitled to charge for sitting together. I do have to ask why they can do this? I would be interested to know how many restaurants you know that charge for customers to sit together? The charge should be part of the ticket price not an extra at the end of the booking process. Charge yes for extra leg room but charging for a standard seat when no service is being provided is appalling. Is £50 for seats a fair cost for booking when the customer actually does the booking.
Another point I wish to make is Jet2 charge if you do not check in online. You do this and as part of this process you have to pay to book the seats. So you are forced to make an additional payment. Also an extra payment is demanded to guarantee that hand luggage goes into the plane and not the hold. It is an absolute scandal and Jet2 can not be bothered to repond to my complaint
The price for the flight should be clearly advertised at the outset. Justifiable extras should also be advertised.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
We booked BA105 LHR-DXB on 28 Feb 2018 and return BA106DXB-LHR  on 15 Mar 2018, in premium-priced seating in BA World Traveller Plus class.
We noticed that sets of seats together were appearing to be rapidly becoming unavailable, so we were effectively forced to purchase seats in advance in order to avoid being split up and seated apart, or to be left with no aisle access between us. At the time of booking our seats there were apparently only 8 seats together that included one aisle seat, and a further 6 central seats available. 
Furthermore, the seat purchase webpage was not functioning properly: we were able to book the set of two seats that were acceptable to us, but not to pay. We had to conclude the transaction by phoning BA passenger services on a 0344 line. 
We consider that BA's policy on advance seat booking is tantamount to extortion. We had to pay £38 per seat on our outbound flight and £43 per seat on our return flight, for a total of £162.00.   On top of already paying £500 for each of the return tickets in this premium economy class. Furthermore it is not clear whether or not the "unavailable" seats have genuinely been purchased, or whether BA is using an AI algorithm to make it appear that window and aisle seats are being avidly gobbled up at £49-38 by real passengers, when they are actually being withheld in order to blackmail customers into paying the extra.
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.167 Safari/537.36

column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13: Flying with my wife and 4 yr old daughter, we were not able to sit together.  This proved difficult as my daughter naturally wanted to see, and be with both of us, so she routinely walked up and down 15 rows of seats to visit both of us individually causing issues for the cabin crew who were busy with the trolleys.  Not only was this a hinderance to other passengers and crew, but I felt was unsafe as had we hit turbulence, my daughter would have been at risk of injury.  May I suggest that more pressure is put on airlines to enable their websites to make available viewing of the booking status of seats BEFORE booking, therefore allowing customers to make an informed choice on which flight to book based on seating availability.  I feel this would help avoid the majority of issues, as customers can self serve their own seating issues.  Not enough airlines provide this

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did sit together
column13: I was caught out by Ryanair when they started "Randomly" allocating middle seats to all passengers who hadn't paid to sit together.  I was travelling with my 12 y/o son and so wanted to be next to him.  We booked the flights together on one booking but when we came to check in we were allocated middle seats, one near the front and one at the rear of the plane.  The airline claimed lack of available seats but on trying to purchase seats together on the same flight there was lots of availability, and indeed on the flight itself when we boarded.  So this was a bogus excuse and clearly a money-making racket.  As a frequent Ryanair traveller it was obvious to me that they had changed the protocol for allocations.  Something they denied.  I complained and they allocated me free seats together for the flight out but not for the return journey because I was unable to check in until I was away.  Ryanair have also reduced the check-in period to four days unless you have paid a premium.  This means one is often unable to checkin at home for the return journey and print boarding passes.  Hence, if one is unlikely to have a printer, one has to pay the premium.

column3: Within the last month
column11: None of these
column13: I live with anxiety and claustrophobia which derive from a phobia I have - emetophobia. It is a fear of vomiting or seeing or hearing others vomiting. I have undergone treatment for my phobia and it has taken me a long time to get to the point where I can travel in a confined environent. Having already upgraded to Premium Economy to sit in a cabin with fewer peopleI then paid £106.00 to British Airways to secure a window seat for myself and an isle seat for my husband. I will not travel without securing such seats as sitting in the usual row of 3 is simply out of the question. These seats are as important to me as the holiday itself. I received proof of purchase and an aircraft plan with our window and isle seat highlighted. Although I have a fear of flying (as a result of my phobia), knowing that we have these seats before flying puts my mind at ease. However, as I embarked the aircraft on a flight from Newark to London, I discovered that these seats had now been allocated to another couple and our seats were now in the middle of a row of 4. I was absolutely mortified and was so distressed that I was led off the aircraft by a kind attendant. The male BA worker at the gate told me that I would need to 'get bach on that plane or catch a later flight'. As my husband was on the plane, I had no choice but to return. I was in tears and feeling very unwell. How could they have changed our window and isle seat (row of 2) to seats in the middle of a row of 4? I would never have travelled or even gone on holiday had I been notified of this in good time. I paid for specific seats for very, very good reasons and my purchase had been completely ignored. When people pay that amount of money simply to select seats, there is usually a good reason for it. Changing our seats to seats I would never have purchased without even a mention of an apology or refund is inexcusable. It caused great distress to myself. I was later moved to an isle seat which helped with my claustrophobia but my husband and I were then seated apart. I struggle to understand how a well-respected company can justify this. How can they offer a service, take their customer's money and then not deliver on this service. I am appalled. I would appreciate any advice before I proceed further with my complaint. Thank you.

column11: We did not sit together because there was no option to do so (e.g. we couldn't select our seats, seats next to each other were already taken, etc.)
column13:
There were two children in the group.  The adult who made the booking for the 6 of us was forced to pay for her seat next to the children who had a free seat alocation.

Of the remaining three people, we were allocated totally random seats around the plane.  We did not know this until we came to check-in online 4 days before.  There was no reason that we couldn't have all sat together as the window and aisle seats either side of my husband's allocated seat were both free.  Obviously the system is designed to split people up.  I paid £10 to move to sit in the aisle seat next to him.  The window seat remained vacant during the flight.  There were very few other empty seats.

We didn't complain to the airline - this was Ryanair, they make their own  rules to benefit themselves, not the customer.

I had expected a lot of people to be moving about in the aisle during the flight as a result of this random seat allocation, but this was not the case.  Obviously a lot of people had paid for their seats prior to the random allocation - there simply weren't enough free seats for many people to have paid the £10 after the allocation as I had.

When we did that we were completely separated  22G for my son, 63J for my husband & 19G for me. we were told the flight was overbooked & we were lucky to get seats. next day flight cancelled & we were bumped to coach for replacement flight1 day later. I question whether we would have been bumped to coach had we paid extra fee. I wonder if we would have to wait a day if for new flight if we paid extra fee.  I also think it is VERY unsafe to seat children apart from parents. FYI When we got to coach, they put us together. I think it is extortion to make families pay to sit next to children.

column3: More than 2 years ago
column11: We did sit together
column13: The staff thought it was perfectly acceptable for two of my children to sit unaccompanied, one of whom was four years old and autistic. Thankfully some other customers overheard and offered to move so that the children wouldn't be seated alone. I don't care where I am seated if travelling with other adults, but children should never be seated alone; it is unsafe for the child and unfair to the other passengers. Also why should parents be forced into a position where they have to pay extra to be seated with their children? Parents don't *want* to be seated with their children: they *need* to be. It's a basic safety requirement that is so often overlooked by greedy airlines.

column3: More than 1 month ago, but within the last 3 months
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13: My partner and I booked the flight together. We checked-in together as usual, as soon as check-in online opened, so there would be plenty of available seats. When we got to the "Seat Selection" area we were assigned seats 10 rows apart, then a message appeared: "You're sitting apart. Would you prefer to sit together?" (I have taken screenshots of the whole process). When we clicked yes, we were presented with the choice: pay between 6 to 20 Euros per person to sit together. What I find outrageous is that in the sitting plan of the plane there were empty seats just next to the ones that we'd both been assigned: we could have been assigned a seat next to each other in the first place, without having to pay extra! It was very clear that the algorithm assigned separate seats on purpose, in spite of empty seats all around, to push passengers to pay extra to seat together. Once on the plane this was confirmed because several other passengers were in our same position, having been separated at online check-in, and sitting 10 or more rows apart. I was incensed, very annoying practice from Ryanair. On the return flight it happened again, we were assigned separate seats 10 rows apart (although there were plenty of empty seats all around), my girlfriend didn't want to sit on her own so we gave in and decided to pay extra to sit together. We selected the 6 Euros option but even that is not accurate: 6 Euros plus whatever fee on top, became 7.65 Euros pp. From our experience it's quite clear that it's a Ryanair practice to squeeze more money out of passangers that have already booked the flight, and either sit separately or pay extra for the luxury of sitting together.

column13: I upgraded to premium economy for me and my partner travelling to Orlando. There are only 24 premium economy seats on the flight and on the outbound leg only 4 seats are shown unallocated, 1 pair and 2 singles meaning a 50/50 chance we’d be split up if I didn’t pay for the seat allocation. The seat booking has added a further 50% to the flight upgrade cost. I’m absolutely disgusted. Premium economy always used to include seat selection gratis.

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did not sit together as we were not bothered enough about being separated to pay extra to sit together
column13: Not seated with my husband for reasons above. On board I was sat in the aisle seat; next to me was a lady who required assisted boarding, next to her was an empty window seat. Across the aisle from me was her husband. What, in allocation of seats, prevented her husband being sat next to her? Before boarding we were told that the seating allocation was because the flight was full. I was sat in about row 9 and there were plenty of empty seats in the rows in front and plenty behind. Most of the couples on board, who had not paid extra, were seated apart, which resulted in ‘musical seats’ once the plane was in the air. Not great from a safety aspect I would think if anything should happen mid air. It was a similar situation on another Ryanair flight four months later. Heard programmes on the radio, and seen reports in newspapers, from customers complaining but Ryanair always deny this is a company policy. Do they really think we are so stupid? They are the ones without brain cells if they think we can’t work it out!

column3: More than 6 months ago, but within the last 12 months
column11: We did sit together
column13: Initially, at the time of booking the five seats on Ryanair's website, we did not choose the option to pay for seats together and thought we'd see what the system generated for us. It was only a short flight LGW-DUB and return so weren't that bothered. However, what came back was completely unacceptable as each of us was allocated a seat in a different row, in a line, moving down the aircraft. It was if the system was generating the worst possible options in order to make us pay for seats together. Well, that worked because we did!  This is a completely unfair system, used by most operators it seems, and has become the norm when we travel and the CAA should address this issue with UK carriers.

column3: Within the last month
column11: We did sit together
column13:
I would prefer not to have to pay extra to guarantee seats together, however it seems likely that Ryanair have recently changed their computerised seat allocation program so that if you choose not to pay extra, it will intentionally seat you apart.  This obviously leads to irritations on the plane, such as people attempting to informally swap seats as they board, people shouting to their companion a few rows down the plane, people blocking the aisles to talk to their companion. 

A separate issue is that of noisy babies/children screaming and banging on the back of one's seat.  I do wish cabin crew would be more proactive in supporting the victims of this!  Why can't noisy/disruptive people be seated in one part of the plane and quiet people in another part?
column20: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/64.0.3282.186 Safari/537.36

column3: Within the last month
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
Ryanair clearly purpose split us up.

I was in 9a, my boyfriend in 32a... the brother and travel companion of  the gent next to me in 9B was sat next to by boyfriend in 32B. The third passenger in our row (9c) was split from her companion who was sat in 32C. We had all been split up ! none of us knew each other but mid way through the flight it all clicked. THIS IS NOT RANDOM, the odds of this are extremely high,  we would have a better chance of winning the lottery on two  consecutive draw dates.

On the way out we paid to sit next to each other but on the way back it was not possible and too expensive. Ryanair made sure that none of the people travelling could  sit next to their companion unless both of us were willing to pay money to move. My boyfriend and I would have both had to pay to move because the seats next to us were 'randomly allocated' to others. This is clearly in money ma king ploy from ryanair and not random at all. This is unfair and concerning.

column3: More than 12 months ago, but within the last 2 years
column11: We wanted to sit together but it was too expensive to pay extra to do so
column13:
I have been flying on American with my family regularly since 2004. My wife and I have a 7 year old grandson whose mother died at the end of 2012. In the summer of 2014 and 2015 we took our grandson on American from MAN to LAX via ORD to spend time with our daughter and her husband in Ventura,CA and in 2016 we booked flights for 23 July 2016 to LAX on 12 May 2016. I complained on 15 May 2016 to AA because I was extremely disappointed that the presentation of seat availability by AA appears to disadvantage families. Clearly with a 7 year old grandson to entertain on flights across the Atlantic and to the West Coast it is essential for my wife and I to sit next to our grandson. When booking 10 weeks before the flight it was not possible to select three seats together on AA55 without paying an extra £252 for 3 Main Cabin Extra seats. For whatever reason, the seats which do not require a premium payment are in rows 14 to 17 and rows 21 to 28 on 15 May 16, when I complained, 20 seats were still shown as available. Of these 20 seats, 17 were the middle seat of a block of three, with 2 aisle seats and 1 window seat available. 17 blocks of 3 seats were showing no availability. 33 seats had been allocated to people who had not chosen to sit next to a companion or fellow traveller (or were reserved for Elite travellers). When I booked there were therefore at least 23 available seats not requiring a premium payment, and yet our party of 3 people (2 grandparents and a grandson) could only get 2 seats together seats 21E & 21H with a further seat behind at 22D. I regard this arrangement as unacceptable for a flight time exceeding 7 hours, but I also consider the extra payment of £252 equally unacceptable. If middle seats are regarded as so inferior there should be a compensation for using them. With the current allocation system, families with children are at a serious disadvantage because middle seats are being avoided rigorously by singles. In the 36 sets of 3 seats, there could be no more than 17 sets of 3 people. We should have been the 18th and yet it had not been possible.

AA replied on 16 May 16 with some suggestions which proved unsuccessful because they have actually designed the system to be like it is. I replied on 17 May 16 including the following "I accept that a single traveller preferring an aisle seat or a window seat may be important to those individuals, but to me the need to be available next to one’s 7 year old grandson during a 7 hour flight ranks above whether a single traveller sits in exactly the seat he chooses, particularly when it is at the cost of three other travellers who are having their choice denied. If someone really insists on an aisle seat or a window seat, I do not see why AA should give that person the opportunity to break into an empty set of 3 seats, when single aisle seats or single window seats are still available in nearby rows, as is the case here, and in my opinion these should be booked up first by the single travellers, until it is really necessary to break into a new empty set of 3 seats."

AA replied on 17 May 16 with a suggestion which was unsuccessful and I wrote a further e-mail on 18 May 16 with the following "Thank you for your reply. I have contacted AA reservations as you suggested. Unfortunately they are unable to help other than by allocating 3 main cabin extra seats at a total cost of £252.90, which is unacceptable to us. They did say that the premium cost can vary with time and that some seats are blocked for the airport staff to unblock during the check-in process, within 24 hours of the flight. This does nothing for our anxiety about the flight over the next 9 weeks, but clarifies our understanding of AA’s lack concern for families travelling with children, no matter how regularly they fly."

The flight in question went ahead on 23 July 2016 and I wrote to AA on 27 August 2016 including the following "I therefore was in the unfortunate situation of spending the whole flight of over 7 hours on a different row to my 7 year old mother-less grandson, whose welfare was left to my 69 year old wife and we regarded the experience as completely unsatisfactory, and a lost opportunity for me to help my wife and spend time with my grandson.Despite this being our 13th year on American,regularly visiting our daughter in the US,sometimes with a party of up to 6 people,we have now concluded that AA do not look after families with young children and do not want our business.
To add to what I have already said in my earlier complaint:The assignment of seats allows single travellers to pick one of a set of 3 unassigned seats, when a similar seat is still available nearby in a row with another seat already assigned. This is unreasonable and unfair to 3 people who wish to sit together.Couples also have a habit of reserving an aisle seat and a window seat,with an unassigned 'middle' seat between them,in the hope of it being untaken.We saw an example of this on AA1576 on 7 Aug(see complaint re that flight for detail).AA could stop both of these problems at the seat assignment stage.Thirdly AA could stop blocking to us 6 seats per row in rows 14 to 17.If the couple in 21C&D had been reassigned by AA to 22C&D,and the single in 22C to 21C, I(22D)could have been moved to 21D to join my family!"

Since this experience in July 2016 we have visited our daughter in California with our UK grandson on 3 further occasions via LAX with another planned trip at Easter 2018. We have not purchased an AA flight since the July 2016 trip. We have never paid a premium to BA for seat allocation.

AA Elite travellers can reserve seats at a discount, but over the years AA have made the qualification for Elite levels more difficult to achieve, and they now offer an annual opportunity to purchase Gold status for a year for a cost of 1249$, which I regard as excessive.  AA's high charges for reserving seats only become evident towards the end of selecting an itinerary in the booking process. This makes the decision making process extremely complex and extended; the only efficient way of booking a flight is not to bother considering American Airlines, unless you are travelling as a single.
